en: Third, CoVs randomly and frequently switch templates during RNA replication through a unique “copy-choice” mechanism.
ff: Tataɓool, CoV ji ɗon saanja ɓaali haa yakke nufturol RNA gal dabare je mbiyotto "copy-choice".

en: In a host that serves as the mixing vessel, strand switching occurs frequently during CoV RNA transcription.
ff: haa nder suudu je ɗon naandi bana tassawo jilugo kujeji, saanjol ɗon salla tum haa yakke windol RNA.

en: Highly homologous full-length and subgenomic RNAs could recombine to generate new CoVs.
ff: RNA je ɗon jutti masin e ɗon naandi foti hawtira ngam keɓɓugo CoV ji keese.

en: Phylogenetic evidence of natural recombination has been found in both HCoV-HKU1 and HCoV-OC43, as well as animal CoVs such as bat SL-CoV and batCoV-HKU9.
ff: Sappinol asngol hawtirde aranool tawama haa HCoV-HKU1 be HCoV-OC43 ɗiɗi fu, be CoV ji daabaji bana bilwili SL-CoV be bilwili CoV-HKU9.

en: Virus-host interaction in relation to transmission
ff: Fiijol suudu viriis be sallinol

en: Besides three viral factors stated above, viral interaction with host receptor is another key factor influential on interspecies transmission.
ff: Ɓesdugo haa kujeji viriis tati je en limti haa dow ndu, fiijol viriis be jaɓɓowo laati kanduɗum masin nder sallinol haa kunde daabaji be neɗɗo.

en: Herein, recombination of SARS-CoV is taken as a typical example, which also showed evidence of positive selection during interspecies transmission events.
ff: Ndu, hawtirde SARS-CoV hoccama bana sappinol kanduɗum, je ɗon holla bo'o suɓɓol bodde haa yakke sallinol haa kunde daabaji be neɗɗo.

en: Based on the comparative analysis between isolates of human and civet SARS-CoVs, SARS-CoV is thought to undergo rapid adaptation in different hosts, particularly with mutations at the RBD of the S protein.
ff: Do lartol do foondol haa cakka SARS-CoV ji neɗɗo be je patuuru je siggotto haa sera, SARS-CoV bana ɗon saanja lau haa nder ɓanndu daabaji malla neɗɗo, ɓurna be saanjolji haa wakere RBD protein S.

en: Generally, the RBD in the S protein of a CoV interacts with the cellular receptor and is intensely selected by the host antibody response.
ff: Ɓurna fu, RBD haa nder protein S CoV feere fiijidan be jaɓɓowo cell e ɗon suɓɓi be hakiika gal jabbuye fadoowo ɓanndu.

en: In SARS-CoV, the RBD is in the 318th to 510th amino acids on the S1 fragment, which binds to the human ACE2 as well as its coreceptors for viral entry.
ff: Nder SARS-CoV, RBD ɗon limmi haa cakka amino acid jje 318 haa 510 haa do ta'irde S1, je ɗon hawta ACE2 be ko ɗon jaɓɓa ndu ngam nastirde viriis.

en: The RBD of SARS-CoV is capable of recognizing the ACE2 receptors of various animals, including bat, civet, mouse and raccoon dog, allowing interspecies transmission of the virus.
ff: RBD je SARS-CoV foti maanda jaɓɓolji ACE2 haa daabaji feere-feere, bana, bilwili, patuuru, doomru be rawandu doomruweela, je ɗon jarfa sallinol viriis haa cakka daabaji be neɗɗo.

en: In fact, only 6 amino acid residues were observed to be different from human and civet viral isolates in the RBD and 4 of them locate in the receptor-binding motif for interaction with the ACE2 receptor.
ff: Be gonga, sna coolaaje amino acid 6 tawama bana feerejo be viriis je siggoto haa sera neɗɗo be patuuru haa nder RBD e 4 haa cakka maɓɓe ɗon wondi haa nder jaɓɓowo hawtirde ngam fiijol be jaɓɓowo ACE2.

en: Civet SARS-CoV has K479N and S487T mutations in its RBD, which might increase the affinity of the interaction of spike protein with human ACE2 receptor.
ff: Saanjolji SARS-CoV woodi K479N be S487T haa nder RBD maaɗa, je foti ɓesda naandol fiiji hoore protein je jaɓɓowo neɗɗo.

en: In other words, these two amino acid substitutions might be critical to viral adaption to humans.
ff: Bana wi'ugo, saanjolji amino acid je ɗiɗi ndu foti lata hannay haa saanjol viriis haa neɗɗo.

en: It is noteworthy that SARS-CoV-2 shares the same cellular receptor with SARS-CoV.
ff: Boɗɗum fammugo yo'o SARS-CoV-2 ɗon mari jaɓɓowo cell gooto be SARS-CoV.

en: A 30% difference between SARS-CoV-2 and SARS-CoV in the S1 unit of the S protein implicates that the binding affinity of its S protein with human ACE2 might have altered.
ff: Feeretirol 30% haa kunde SARS-CoV-2 be SARS-CoV haa nder toɓe S1 protein S yiɗi wi'ugo yo'o naandol hawtirde protein S maaɗa be ACE2 neɗɗo saanji.

en: Indeed, a cryo-EM study indicates a 10- to 20-fold higher affinity of this binding than that between human ACE2 and SARS-CoV S protein.
ff: Gonga, jaangirde cryo-EM ɗon holla naandol je nde 10 haa 20 je ɓuri do je haa cakka ACE2 neɗɗo be protein S ACE2 be SARS-CoV.

en: It will also be of interest to determine whether any other coreceptor might be required for SARS-CoV-2 transmission.
ff: Wonan bo'o kanduɗum ngam fammugo to woodi jaɓɓowo feere je foti emmotto ngam sallinol SARS-CoV-2.

en: Intriguingly, HCoV-NL63 also binds to ACE2 but with a different part of S.
ff: Ko ɗon hilna, HCoV-NL63 ɗon hawta be ACE2 amma be ta'irde S feere.

en: There exist many other HCoV receptors, such as aminopeptidase N for HCoV-229E, and 9-O-acetylated sialic acid for HCoV-OC43.
ff: woodi jaɓɓoɓe HCoV feere, bana aminopeptidase N je HCoV-229E, be 9-O-acetylated sialic acid je HCoV-OC43.

en: They might also account for successful adaptation of these CoVs in humans after interspecies transmission from their animal hosts.
ff: foti ɓe naffa ngam saanjol CoV ji haa nder ɓanndu neɗɗo haa ɓaawo sallinol haa kunde daabaji diga suudu siggorde maɓɓe.

en: In addition to cellular receptors, the outcome of interspecies transmission of HCoVs is also governed by other host dependency and restriction factors.
ff: Ɓesdugo haa jaɓɓoɓe cellji, sappinol sallinol HCoV ji haa kunde daabaji je kujeji siggorde feere on fadatta ndu.

en: The divergence of these host proteins between humans and natural reservoir hosts of HCoVs such as bats, dromedary camels and rodents might constitute a barrier to interspecies transmission.
ff: Feeretirol cuuɗi proteinji je ɗon woni haa kunde neɗɗo he cuuɗi siggorde HCoV ji bana bilwili, ngeelobaji, malla nyamooɓe foti wona ko haɗatta sallinol haa kunde daabaji.

en: HCoVs have to usurp host dependency factors and subvert host restriction factors for a successful interspecies transmission.
ff: HCoV ji sey njaamba wondugo do kujeji fadol e saanja ko haɗatta hadol heɓɓa sallinol haa kunde daabaji salla boɗɗum.

en: In this regard, molecular determinants in this important area of virus-host interaction remain to be identified and characterized.
ff: Bana ni, sappinooɓe molekulji haa nder wakkere fiiji suudu viriis sey manda ɗum e hokka kugal maaɗa.

en: An unbiased genome-wide screening of host dependency and restriction factors for SARS-CoV-2 using the state-of-the-art technology of CRISPR might be fruitful.
ff: woodi lartol maungel feere je wala suɓɓol feere do suudu SARS-CoV-2 be kujeji ustugo gal dabare CRISPR foti hokka ɓiɓe.

en: Emergence of novel HCoVs: back to ground zero
ff: Wangol HCoV ji keese: lortol haa fuɗɗorde

en: The diversity of bat CoVs provides ample opportunities for the emergence of novel HCoVs.
ff: Waagare CoV ji ɗon hokka dabareji ɗuɗɗum ngam wangol HCoV ji keese.

en: In this sense, bat CoVs serve as the gene pool of HCoVs.
ff: Nden kadi, CoV ji bilwili laati bana ɓundu gene HCoV ji.

en: In addition, rapid mutation and genetic recombination also drive HCoV evolution and serve as two important steps in this process.
ff: haa ɓesdugo, saanjol laugel be hawtirde asngol foti bo'o ngaɗa yahde HCoV e wurtira ta'irdeji ɗiɗi nder laahal ndu.

en: For example, the acquisition or loss of novel protein-coding genes has the potential to drastically modify viral phenotypes.
ff: Bana sappinol, keɓɓol malla majjol geneji protein je keese foti saanja phenotypeji viriis be boɗɗum.

en: Among SARS-CoV accessory proteins, ORF8 has been thought to be important in adaptation to humans, as SARS-CoV-related bat viruses were isolated but found to encode divergent ORF8 proteins.
ff: haa kunde proteinji mballol SARS-CoV, ORF8 laati bana kanduɗum nder saanjol haa nder neɗɗo, bana viriisji bilwili SARS-CoV siggotto haa sera amma laati bana mari lamba proteinji ORF8 feere.

en: A 29-nucleotide deletion characteristic of SARS-CoVs has been found in strains isolated at the beginning of the human epidemic.
ff: Wilugo 29-nucleotide je laati maandirɗum SARS-CoVs tawama haa nder gildiji je siggotto haa sera haa fuɗɗorde nyau haa neɗɗo.

en: This deletion splits ORF8 into ORF8a and ORF8b and is thought to be an adaptive mutation that promotes the switch of hosts.
ff: Willol ndu ɗon senda ORF8 haa ORF8a be ORF8b e tammi latugo bana saajonl je ɗon walla saanjol cuuɗi.

en: Besides, SARS-CoV has a possible recombination history with lineages of alpha- and gamma-CoVs, where a large number of smaller recombinant regions were identified in the RNA-dependent RNA polymerase.
ff: Fahin, SARS-CoV foti mara tariya hawtirol be asli CoV ji alpha- be gamma, e limgal wakkere hawtirooɓe maungel be pamaron tawama haa nder polymerase RNA je jooɗi do RNA.

en: Recombination locations were also identified in the nsp9, most of nsp10, and parts of nsp14.
ff: Wakkereji hawtirolji tawama bo'o haa nder nsp9, ɓurna nsp10, e ta'irdeji nsp14.

en: Likewise, it has been shown that the epidemic MERS-CoV experienced recombination events between different lineages, which occurred in dromedary camels in Saudi Arabia.
ff: Fahin bo'o, be sappini yo'o nyau MERS-CoV hawti kujejiha kunde asli feere-feere, je wangi haa ngeelobaji haa Saudi Arabiya.

en: Besides SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV, recombination events have also been observed in other HCoVs, in which the HCoVs recombine with other animal CoVs in their non-structural genes.
ff: haa ɓesdugo SARS-CoV be MERS-CoV, kujeji hawtirde maandama haa HCoV ji feere, nder ton HCoV ji ɗon hawtira be CoV ji daaba feere haa nder geneji maɓɓe je maray ɓanndu je ɗon aandin.

en: It should also be cautioned that artificial selection can contribute to unintended changes in viral genomes, most likely resulting from relieving viruses from selection pressures exerted, such as by the host immune system.
ff: Sey famma bo'o yo'o suɓɓol feere foti naffa ngam saanjol genomji viriis je tammay sam, ɓurna je ummiki haa viriisji haa suɓɓol jaawalji, bana dabare fadol suudu.

en: An example of these effects is the loss of a full-length ORF4 in the HCoV-229E prototype strain, owing to a two-nucleotide deletion.
ff: Sappinol kujeji ndu laati majjol ORF4 je juttungel haa nder irin gilɗi HCoV-229E, je ɗon laarani willol nucleotideji ɗiɗi.

en: While intact ORF4 could be observed in bat and camel viruses related to HCoV-229E, the alpaca alpha-CoV displays a single nucleotide insertion, resulting in a frameshift.
ff: haa wakkati je ORF4 je ɗon wondi foti tawama haa nder viriisji bilwili be ngeeloba je laarani HCoV-229E, alpha-CoV je alpaka ɗon sappina nastirde nucleotide woore, je ngaɗan saanjol ɓanndu.

en: Last but not least, the evolution of novel HCoVs is also driven by the selection pressure in their reservoir hosts.
ff: Ragare amma kanduɗum, yahde HCoV ji ngadama gal suɓɓol jaawal haa nder cuuɗi siggorde.

en: Asymptomatic or only mild symptoms were detected when bats were infected with CoVs, indicating the mutual adaptation between CoVs and bats.
ff: Mandolji nyau je fammatakke malla je deydey tan tawama haa yakke je bilwili raɓɓi CoV ji, je sappinatta saanjol oya be oya haa kunde CoV ji be bilwili.

en: It appeared that bats are well adapted to CoVs anatomically and physiologically.
ff: Salli bana bilwili ɗon yahida be boɗɗum be CoV ji gal ɓanndu maɓɓe be huwirde maɓɓe fu.

en: For example, defects in the activation of pro-inflammatory response in bats efficiently reduce the pathology triggered by CoVs.
ff: Bana sappinol, harbuggo nder umminugo jabbuye do ko foti ngaɗa huudure haa nder bilwili ɗon usta be boɗɗum nawnol je CoV ji wadi.

en: Besides, the natural killer cell activity in bats is suppressed due to upregulation of inhibitory natural killer cell receptor NKG2/CD94 and low expression level of major histocompatibility complex class I molecules.
ff: haa ɓesdugo, kuje je ɗon mbarda yimɓe haa nder bilwili wilakke ngam wangugo kuje je ɗon mbara go NKG2/CD94 be lessugo ngu

en: Moreover, the high level of reactive oxygen species (ROS) generated from high metabolic activity of bats could both suppress CoV replication and affects proofreading by exoribonuclease, thus providing the selection pressure for the generation of virus strains highly pathogenic when introduced into a new host.
ff: Fahin bo'o, limtol hendu je ɗon ɗuɗɗum (ROS) wangi gal kuɗe nyamɗe haa bilwili je foti willa nuftol CoV e memma jaangirde gal exoribonuclease, ndu ɗon ngaɗa jaawal do asli bilwili je ɗon nyaɗungel to bana nastidi haa nder suudu keesum.

en: More pathogenic CoV strains might also evolve by recombination, leading to the acquisition of novel proteins or protein features for host adaptation.
ff: Gilɗi CoV ɗuɗɗum je nyaɗungel foti bo'o yahida gal hawtirde, je ɗon ndokka proteinji keese malla mandolji protein ngam saanjol suudu.

en: Thus, it is not by chance that three novel HCoVs have emerged in the past two decades.
ff: Nden kadi, latay sa'a je HCoV ji keese tati wangi haa nder duuɓi cappan ɗiɗi je sallingo.

en: CoVs are non-pathogenic or cause mild symptoms in their reservoir hosts such as bats and camels.
ff: CoV ji wonay nyaɗungel malla ɗon sappina mandolji nyau deydey haa nder suudu jaɓɓowo bana bilwili be ngeelobaji.

en: They replicate robustly without eliciting a strong host immune response.
ff: Ɓe ɗon nufta be sembe bila emmugo jabbuye je caɗɗum haa fadooɓe ɓanndu.

en: Herein lie the secrets of why asymptomatic carriers are seen and what causes the severe cases in human infection.
ff: haa do on woni siiriji je koni rondooɓe je sappinatta mandolji tawama e ɗumme on ngaɗi nyau je ɗon torra neɗɗo.

en: The severe symptoms are mainly due to the hyperactivation of immune response and the cytokine storm wherein the stronger the immune response, the more severe the lung damage.
ff: Mandolji nyau je nyaɗungel ɓurna fu ɗon wanga ngam jabbuye fadol ɓanndu be duluru cytokine je ɗon woni jur, ngam to bana jabbuye fadol ɓanndu ɗon wa'a, bana ni bo'o nawne fuffu ɗon ɓesda.

en: In contrast, in asymptomatic carriers, the immune response has been de-coupled from CoV replication.
ff: Be man fu, haa nder rondooɓe je nyaday ndu, jabbuye fadol laati sendirama be nuftol CoV.

en: The same strategy of delinking the immune response might have beneficial effects in anti-SARS-CoV-2 therapy.
ff: Irin dabare sendirugo jabbuye fadol foti woni kanduɗum haa nder hurgol anti-SARS-CoV-2.

en: The interferon response is particularly strong in bats.
ff: Jabbuye interferon laati bana mari sembe jur haa bilwili.

en: Thus, administration of type I interferon at least in the early phase of SARS-CoV-2 infection in humans should be beneficial.
ff: Bana ni, hokkugo interferon type I pettum man haa fuɗɗam yahde nyau SARS-CoV-2 haa neɗɗo wonan kanduɗum.

en: In addition, NLRP3 inflammasome activation in bats is defective.
ff: Fahin bo'o, je be wi'i bilwili ɗon ndokka nyau NLRP3 yahay be lawol.

en: By this reasoning, inhibition of NLRP3 inflammasome with MCC950 might be useful in the treatment of COVID-19.
ff: Gal irin nummolji, illol NLRP3 inflammasome be MCC950 foti naffa haa nder hurgol COVID-19.

en: The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 follows the general theme by which SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV arose.
ff: Jaawal SARS-CoV-2 ɗon tokkita hoore ngewte laungel gal nden SARS-CoV be MERS-CoV wangi.

en: Whereas a bat beta-CoV sharing 95% nucleotide homology with SARS-CoV has been found, there also exists a bat-CoV sharing 96% nucleotide homology with SARS-CoV-2.
ff: haa yakke je sendol 95% naandol nucleotide be SARS-CoV tawama, woodi bo'o sendol CoV bilwili 96% naandol nucleotide be SARS-CoV-2.

en: Whereas civets and other animals in the markets have been found to harbour viruses identical to SARS-CoV, immediate intermediate hosts for SARS-CoV-2 have not been identified.
ff: haa wakkati je pattuji be daabaji feere haa nder lumo tawama bana siggotto viriisji je ɗon naandi SARS-CoV haa nder ɓanndu maɓɓe, suudu siggorde je aranol SARS-CoV-2 tawakke tawon.

en: Pangolin beta-CoVs strikingly homologous to SARS-CoV-2 have been found, indicating that pangolins might serve as one of intermediate hosts or pangolin beta-CoVs could contribute gene fragments to the final version of SARS-CoV-2.
ff: Beta-CoV ji pangolin je ɗon naandi masitin be SARS-CoV-2 tawama, ko hollatta yo'o pangoliji foti wona bana suudu siggorde cakare malla beta-CoV ji foti walla ta'irdeji gene nder ragare SARS-CoV-2.

en: Although questions remain, there is no evidence that SARS-CoV-2 is man-made either deliberately or accidentally.
ff: Ko to emmolji wondan, ɗon aandin yo'o SARS-CoV-2 neɗɗo on wadi ndu be aniyaa malla yotti bana ni tan.

en: CoVs have returned to the limelight due to the recent outbreak of SARS-CoV-2.
ff: CoV ji lorti fahin ngam yottol nyau SARS-CoV-2 je keese.

en: The study of CoVs in bats and other animals has drastically changed our perception of the importance of zoonotic origins and animal reservoirs of HCoVs in human transmission.
ff: Jaangirde CoV ji haa nder bilwili be daabaji feere saanji nummolji amin fu do ko laarani naffuda wangol gal daabaji be cuuɗi siggorde HCoV ji haa do sallinol nder ɓanndu neɗɗo.

en: Pervasive evidence has shown that SARS-CoV, MERS-CoV and SARS-CoV-2 have a bat origin and are transmitted to humans via intermediate hosts.
ff: Sappinol je ɗon lara be gite holli yo'o SARS-CoV, MERS-CoV be SARS-CoV-2 ummi haa bilwili e sallini haa neɗɗo gal daabaji feere.

en: Given that SARS-CoV infection originates from the contact between humans and civets in the markets, closing wet markets and killing civets therein could have effectively ended the SARS epidemic.
ff: Nde nyau SARS-CoV ummi gal kawtirde neɗɗo be patuuji haa nder lumo, maɓɓol lumo je sippata daabaji je ɗon nyeeɓa be hirsugo patuuji haa ton foti darni no nyau SARS.

en: By the same reasoning, pangolins should be removed from wet markets to prevent zoonotic transmission, in view of the discovery of multiple lineages of pangolin beta-CoVs closely related to SARS-CoV-2.
ff: Gal irin nummolji ndu, pangolinji sey wona wurtama haa lumoji ngam haɗɗugo ta raɓɓol salla gal daabaji, bana sappinol je ɗon holla naandolji beta-CoV ji paangolin be SARS-CoV-2.

en: However, whether and how SARS-CoV-2 is transmitted to humans through pangolins and other mammals remain to be clarified in future investigations.
ff: Amma, to SARS-CoV-2 ɗon sallini haa neɗɗo gal pangolinji be daabaji feere e noy sey laɓɓina ɗum haa nder teffolji je warango.

en: On the other hand, MERS-CoV has existed in dromedary camels for a long time.
ff: haa yakke feere, MERS-CoV woni no haa nder ngeelobaji diga naane maa.

en: These camels serve as an important tool for transportation as well as a main source of meat, milk, leather and wool products for the local people.
ff: Ngeelobaji ndu laati bana kuje je naffata ngam jaahangal e hoorugo kujeji e ɗon hokka kuusel, kossam, laaral be gaasa haa ummatore.

en: They are widely distributed across the Middle East and Africa.
ff: Ɓe ɗon sendama ko to fu haa cakare Funaange be Afirika.

en: It is therefore impossible to sacrifice all camels for the control of MERS, as what was done in wild animal markets in China to prevent the spreading of SARS-CoV and SARS-CoV-2.
ff: Footay bo'o en mbarda ngeelobaji fu ngam natinugo MERS, be ko ɓe waɗi haa lumo daabaji haa Cayna ngam aynol sankittol SARS-CoV be SARS-CoV-2.

en: To stop the recurrent outbreaks of MERS, a comprehensive approach should be taken to develop effective vaccines against MERS-CoV for camels, in combination with other infection control measures.
ff: Ngam darnugo lortolji nyau MERS, woodi dabare feere wangi ngam wurtinugo baatalji MERS-CoV je ngeelobaji, hawti be dabareji aynugo nyauji feere.

en: As we are not able to eliminate these viruses, new genotypes might emerge to cause outbreaks.
ff: Ngam footay en natina viriisji ndu, genotypeji feere foti wanga e hokka nyauji feere fahin.

en: A variety of zoonotic CoVs are circulating in the wild.
ff: Waagare CoV ji je wangi gal daabaji ɗon tara haa nder ladde.

en: Particularly, bat CoVs with zoonotic potential are so diverse.
ff: Ɓurna bo'o, CoV ji bilwili je foti wangi gal daabaji ɗon waagi.

en: There are plenty of opportunities that these zoonotic CoVs evolve and recombine, resulting in the emergence of new CoVs that are more transmissible and/or deadly in humans in future.
ff: woodi dabareji ɓuɗɗum je CoV ji je sallata gal daabaji ndu yahida e hawtida, je ndokatta CoV ji keesum je latan ɓuri raɓɓugo e/malla mbardan yimɓe haa yeeso.

en: The culture of eating wild animals in some places of China should be abandoned to reduce unnecessary contact between humans and animals.
ff: Nyamugo daabaji ladde haa wakkereji feere haa Cayna sey acca ɗum ngam ustugo hawtirol haa kunde neɗɗo be daabaji.

en: With the ordeals of SARS, MERS and COVID-19, a better preparedness and response plan should be in place.
ff: Be larulaaji SARS, MERS be COVID-19, sey taska boɗɗum e heɓɓa jaahargal jabbuye kanduɗum wonda.

en: In fact, many viruses have existed in the planet for a very long time.
ff: Be gonga, viriisji ɗuɗɗum woni no haa do lesdi meɗen diga aran.

en: They stay in their own natural reservoirs until there is a chance for spillover.
ff: Ɓe ɗon woni haa nder cuuɗi siggorde maɓɓe haa wakkati sankittol maɓɓe.

en: Although bats have many features that favours the spreading of viruses, the chance for humans to be in contact with bats and other wildlife species can be minimized if people are educated to stay away from them.
ff: Ko to bilwili ɗon mari dabareji ɗuɗɗum ngam sankittugo viriisji, sa'a haa neɗɗo hawtira be bilwili be daabaji feere foti ustotto to yimɓe emmotto ta be wonda be maɓɓe sam.

en: Continuous surveillance in mammals is necessary for better understanding of the ecology of CoVs and their natural hosts, which will prove useful in preventing animal-to-human transmission and future outbreaks.
ff: Tokkitol aynol haa daabaji naffan ngam fammugo baabal jonde CoV be wakkere jonde maɓɓe je gonga, je sappinan noy haddugo nyau diga daabaji haa neɗɗo be nyau je foti wara haa yeeso.

en: To conclude, the most effective way to prevent viral zoonosis is for humans to stay away from the ecological niches of the natural reservoirs of the zoonotic viruses.
ff: Ngam timminugo, dabare kanduɗum ngam aynugo raɓɓol viriis diga daabaji sey neɗɗo daaya be wakere cuuɗi siggordeji viriisji ndu.

en: Several pieces in the puzzle of the zoonotic origin of SARS-CoV-2 are still missing.
ff: Kujeji jur haa nder nukkure je wangol SARS-CoV-2 gal daabaji wala ɗon.

en: First, if bats transmit an ancestral virus of SARS-CoV-2 to pangolins, it will be of interest to see under what circumstances bats and pangolins could share the same ecological niche.
ff: Aranool, to bilwili ɗon sallina maama viriis SARS-CoV-2 haa pangolji, naffan masin to en teffi noy bilwili be pangolin maran wakkere jonde gooto.

en: Second, if bats play a more direct role in human transmission, how humans get into contact with bats should be determined.
ff: Ɗiɗaɓool, to bilwili laati sallinowo haa neɗɗo, noy neɗɗo hawtidi be bilwili sey aanda ɗum bo'o.

en: Third, if a third mammal acts as the true intermediate host, how it interacts with the different species including humans, bats and pangolins has to be clarified.
ff: Tataɓool, to woodi tataɓool daaba je laati bana siggorde je cakare, sey laɓɓina noy fiijira be daabaji feere e laarani bo'o neɗɗo, bilwili be pangolinji.

en: Finally, since many mammals including domestic animals might be susceptible to SARS-CoV-2, both surveillance and experimental infection should be conducted.
ff: Timminool, nde dabaaji ɗuɗɗum be daabaji saare foti mara SARS-CoV-2, ɗiɗi fu aynol be teffol nyau sey wonotto.

en: Should it be a bat, a pangolin or another mammal, it is expected that SARS-CoV-2 or its parental viruses that are almost identical will be identified in its natural hosts in future.
ff: Ko to woni bilwili, pangolin malla daaba feere, min yidi fammugo yo'o viriisji SARS-CoV-2 malla maama maaɗa je ɗon naandi masitin haa nder suudu siggorde aranool.

en: Continued investigations in this area will elucidate the evolutionary pathway of SARS-CoV-2 in animals, with important implications in the prevention and control of COVID-19 in humans.
ff: Teffol je tokkitata haa nder wakkere nde laɓɓinan yahde SARS-CoV-2 haa nder daabaji, be dabareji ɗuɗɗum nder aynol e lartol COVID-19 haa nder ɓanndu neɗɗo.

en: Preliminary Estimates of the Prevalence of Selected Underlying Health Conditions Among Patients with Coronavirus Disease 2019 — United States, February 12–March 28, 2020
ff: Preliminary Estimates of the Prevalence of Selected Underlying Health Conditions Among Patients with Coronavirus Disease 2019 — United States, 12 Feviriye –28 Maars 2020

en: On March 11, 2020, the World Health Organization declared Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) a pandemic.
ff: haa 11 Maars 2020, Ɗowirde Duniyaru do Jam ɓanndu holli yo'o Nyau Koronaviriis 2019 (COVID-19) laati nyau duniyaru fu.

en: As of March 28, 2020, a total of 571,678 confirmed COVID-19 cases and 26,494 deaths have been reported worldwide.
ff: Diga 28 Maars 2020, hawti nyauɓe COVID-19 571 678 tawama be yimɓe 26 494 maynama haa nder duniyaru fu.

en: Reports from China and Italy suggest that risk factors for severe disease include older age and the presence of at least one of several underlying health conditions.
ff: Kuubaruji gal Cayna be Italy ɗon hollina yo'o kujeji je ɗon saɗɗina nyau man laarani duɗɗi be wondugo nyau feere-feere haa nder ɓanndu.

en: U.S. older adults, including those aged ≥65 years and particularly those aged ≥85 years, also appear to be at higher risk for severe COVID-19–associated outcomes; however, data describing underlying health conditions among U.S. COVID-19 patients have not yet been reported.
ff: Mauɓe haa Lesdi America, be ɓe'en je mari duuɓi ≥65 e ɓurna be'en je ɗon mari duuɓi ≥85, ɗon sappini bana mari sa'a jur raɓɓugo nyau COVID-19–je nyaɗungel; amma, matinolji je ɗon sappina nyauji haa kunde nyau COVID-19 haa Lesdi America matinay tawon.

en: As of March 28, 2020, U.S. states and territories have reported 122,653 U.S. COVID-19 cases to CDC, including 7,162 (5.8%) for whom data on underlying health conditions and other known risk factors for severe outcomes from respiratory infections were reported.
ff: haa 28 Maars 2020, lesɗe be lamordeji Lesdi America matini nyauɓe COVID-19 122 653 haa CDC, be 7 162 (5.8%) je nyau maɓɓe ɗon nyaɗi ɓe feere'en aandin ɗon no mari nyau pofɗe.

en: Among these 7,162 cases, 2,692 (37.6%) patients had one or more underlying health condition or risk factor, and 4,470 (62.4%) had none of these conditions reported.
ff: haa cakka maɓɓe nyauɓe 7 162, 2 692 (37.6%) ɗon mari no tawon nyau malla nyauji feere malla ko foti nyaɗinatta, be 4 470 (62.4%) maray ko gootel haa cakka nyauji ndu.

en: The percentage of COVID-19 patients with at least one underlying health condition or risk factor was higher among those requiring intensive care unit (ICU) admission (358 of 457, 78%) and those requiring hospitalization without ICU admission (732 of 1,037, 71%) than that among those who were not hospitalized (1,388 of 5,143, 27%).
ff: Limtol nyauɓe COVID-19 be pettum man nyau feere gootel malla ko foti nyaɓinatta woni ɗuɗɗum haa cakka ɓe'en je mari no haaje suklare feerejo (ICU) (358 do 457, 78%) e ɓe'en je ɓon mari haaje wondugo haa suudu lekkibila ICU (732 do 1 037, 71%) do ɓe'en je wonday haa suudu lekki (1 388 do 5 143, 27%).

en: The most commonly reported conditions were diabetes mellitus, chronic lung disease, and cardiovascular disease.
ff: Nyauji je ɓurna fu je matinama laati nyau sukkar mellitus, nyau fuffu je ɗon tokkita, nyau ɓernde.

en: These preliminary findings suggest that in the United States, persons with underlying health conditions or other recognized risk factors for severe outcomes from respiratory infections appear to be at a higher risk for severe disease from COVID-19 than are persons without these conditions.
ff: Arandere sappinolji ndu ɗon holla yo'o, haa Lesdi America, yimɓe je ɗon mari nyau feere malla ko foti nyaɗinatta larulaaji nder pofɗe laati bana nyau COVID-19 ɓuri nyaɗugo do yimɓe je maray irin nyauji ndu.

en: Data from laboratory-confirmed COVID-19 cases reported to CDC from 50 states, four U.S. territories and affiliated islands, the District of Columbia, and New York City with February 12–March 28, 2020 onset dates were analyzed.
ff: Matinolji je wurti haa suudu lartol aandini nyauɓe COVID-19 je lesɗe 50 haa CDC, lamordeji Lesdi America nay be lesɗe nder nyiyam je ɗon tardi, Distrik je Columbia, be New York City be fuɗɗorde haa 12 Feviriye–28 Maars 2020.

en: Cases among persons repatriated to the United States from Wuhan, China, and the Diamond Princess cruise ship were excluded.
ff: Nyauɓe haa cakka yimɓe je warti diga Wuhan, Cayna, be je wondi no haa nder kombeewool mbiyotto Diamond Princess haa Lesdi America limay haa cakka man.

en: For cases with missing onset dates, date of onset was estimated by subtracting 4 days (median interval from symptom onset to specimen collection date among cases with known dates in these data) from the earliest specimen collection.
ff: Ko laarani nyauɓe je aanda wakkati fuɗɗorde nde, wakkati fuɗɗorde tammotto gal ustugo balɗe 4 (wakkati je cakare diga fuɗɗam mandol haa wakkati hoccol leeku lartol haa cakka nyauɓe je wakkati fuɗɗorde maɓɓe ɗon aandin) diga hoccol aranol leeku lartol.

en: Public health departments reported cases to CDC using a standardized case report form that captures information (yes, no, or unknown) on the following conditions and potential risk factors: chronic lung disease (inclusive of asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease [COPD], and emphysema); diabetes mellitus; cardiovascular disease; chronic renal disease; chronic liver disease; immunocompromised condition; neurologic disorder, neurodevelopmental, or intellectual disability; pregnancy; current smoking status; former smoking status; or other chronic disease.
ff: Geebeji je suklata do jam ɓanndu matini nyauɓe haa CDC gal hoccugo batakewol matinol nyau je jabbinatta do matinolji be (oho, kay, malla aandakke) do nyauji feere be ko nyaɗinatta ndu: nyau fuffu je ɗon tokkita (be nyau dole, nyau je ɗon haɗɗa foofugo [COPD], be emphysema); nyau sukkar mellitus; nyau ɓernde; nyau ɓooye je ɗon tokkita, nyau hengre je ɗon tokkita, tampere ɓanndu; nyau ngaandi, nyau hoore, malla nyau hakkilo; wonugo be reedu; foɗɗol tabba je aran; malla nyau je ɗon tokkiti maa tum.

en: Data reported to CDC are preliminary and can be updated by health departments over time; critical data elements might be missing at the time of initial report; thus, this analysis is descriptive, and no statistical comparisons could be made.
ff: Matinolji je ɓe neldi haa CDC laati bana je aranool e foti geeɓeji jam ɓanndu larta ndu be wakkati; matinolji je kanduɗum foti wonay tawon haa yakke bindol batakkewol aranol; nden kadi, lartol ndu laati bana ɗon limta kujeji, e footay waɗa foondolji.

en: The percentages of patients of all ages with underlying health conditions who were not hospitalized, hospitalized without ICU admission, and hospitalized with ICU admission were calculated.
ff: Limtolji nyauɓe duuɓi fu je ɗon mari nyauji feere je wonday haa suudu lekki, wondi haa suudu lekki amma bila neldol haa ICU, ɓe'en je wondi haa suudu lekki be neldol haa ICU ɗon limti nder ton.

en: Percentages of hospitalizations with and without ICU admission were estimated for persons aged ≥19 years with and without underlying health conditions.
ff: Limtol wondugo haa suudu lekki be wala neldol haa ICU woni no bana je yimɓe je duuɓi maɓɓe waɗi ≥19 be je mari malla maray nyau feere.

en: This part of the analysis was limited to persons aged ≥19 years because of the small sample size of cases in children with reported underlying health conditions (N = 32).
ff: Ta'irde lartol ndu laarani no yimɓe je mari duuɓi ≥19 ngam limgal nyauɓe je wonay jur haa kunde ɓikkon je ɗon mari nyauji feere (N = 32).

en: To account for missing data among these preliminary reports, ranges were estimated with a lower bound including cases with both known and unknown status for hospitalization with and without ICU admission as the denominator and an upper bound using only cases with known outcome status as the denominator.
ff: Ngam wolwugo do matinolji je wala haa nder aranool batakkewolji, yahde tawama no be keerol nyauɓe les je nyau maɓɓe andi e je aandakke ngam wondugo haa suudu lekki be malla bila neldol haa ICU bana ko hawtatta ɓe e be keerol je do be nyauɓe je nyau maɓɓe ɗon aandin bana ko hawtatta ɓe.

en: Because of small sample size and missing data on underlying health conditions among COVID-19 patients who died, case-fatality rates for persons with and without underlying conditions were not estimated.
ff: Ngam leeku man ɗon pamaron e wala matinolji do larulaaji haa kunde nyauɓe COVID-19 je maynama, limtol mayde je yimɓe je ɗon mari be je maray larulaaji je foti hoosa bana sappinol nastay nder limgal.

en: As of March 28, 2020, a total of 122,653 laboratory-confirmed COVID-19 cases (Figure) and 2,112 deaths were reported to CDC.
ff: haa 28 Maars 2020, haa cakka nyauɓe COVID-19 122 653 je suudu lartol matini (Foto) be 2 112 maynama matinotto haa CDC.

en: Case report forms were submitted to CDC for 74,439 (60.7%) cases.
ff: Batakkeji nyau neldotto haa CDC ngam nyauɓe 74 439 (60.7%).

en: Data on presence or absence of underlying health conditions and other recognized risk factors for severe outcomes from respiratory infections (i.e., smoking and pregnancy) were available for 7,162 (5.8%) patients (Table 1).
ff: Matinolji do wondugo malla wala wondugo nyauji feere malla ko foti nyaɗina ndu ngam nyauji pofɗe (bana wi'ugo, fooɗugo be wondugo be reedu) ɗon woni ngam nyauɓe 7 162 (5.8) (Tabaal 1).

en: Approximately one third of these patients (2,692, 37.6%), had at least one underlying condition or risk factor.
ff: Ɓadi gooto nder tati do nyauɓe ndu (2 692, 37.7%) mari no nyau feere gooto malla ko foti nyaɗina dum.

en: Diabetes mellitus (784, 10.9%), chronic lung disease (656, 9.2%), and cardiovascular disease (647, 9.0%) were the most frequently reported conditions among all cases.
ff: Nyau sukkar mellitus (784, 10.9%), nyau fuffu je ɗon tokkita (656, 9.2%), be nyau ɓernde (647, 9.0%) laati ɓurna nyauji je ɗon matini haa cakka nyauji feere.

en: Among 457 ICU admissions and 1,037 non-ICU hospitalizations, 358 (78%) and 732 (71%), respectively occurred among persons with one or more reported underlying health condition.
ff: haa cakka neldoji 457 haa ICU e wala wondugo haa suudu lekki be walla neldol haa ICU, 358 (78%) be 732 (71%), yotti haa kunde yimɓe je ɗon mari nyau feere gooto malla ɓuri.

en: In contrast, 1,388 of 5,143 (27%) COVID-19 patients who were not hospitalized were reported to have at least one underlying health condition.
ff: haa yakke feere bo'o, 1 388 haa nder 5 143 nyauɓe COVID-19 je wonday no haa suudu lekki matinotto bana mari pettum man nyau feere gooto.

en: Among patients aged ≥19 years, the percentage of non-ICU hospitalizations was higher among those with underlying health conditions (27.3%–29.8%) than among those without underlying health conditions (7.2%–7.8%); the percentage of cases that resulted in an ICU admission was also higher for those with underlying health conditions (13.3%–14.5%) than those without these conditions (2.2%–2.4%) (Table 2).
ff: haa cakka nyauɓe je mari duuɓi ≥19, limtol nyauɓe je wonday haa suudu lekki e wonay haa ICU ɓuri je ɓe'en je ɗon mari nyauji feere (27.3%–29.8%) do ɓe'en je maray nyau feere (7.2%–7.8%); limtol nyauɓe je ɓe neldi haa ICU woni bo'o haa do je ɓe'en je ɗon mari nyauji feere (13.3%–14.5%) do ɓe'en je maray nyauji feere (2.2%–2.4%) (Tabaal 2).

en: Small numbers of COVID-19 patients aged < 19 years were reported to be hospitalized (48) or admitted to an ICU (eight).
ff: Limgal nyauɓe COVID-19 seeɗa je mari duuɓi < 19 mbiyotto bana wondi haa suudu lekki (48) malla je neldotto haa ICU (joowey e tati).

en: In contrast, 335 patients aged < 19 years were not hospitalized and 1,342 had missing data on hospitalization.
ff: haa wakkere feere, nyauɓe 335 je ɗon mari duuɓi < 19 wonday haa nder suudu lekki be 1 342 je maray matinolji do wondugo haa suudu lekki.

en: Among all COVID-19 patients with complete information on underlying conditions or risk factors, 184 deaths occurred (all among patients aged ≥19 years); 173 deaths (94%) were reported among patients with at least one underlying condition.
ff: haa cakka nyauɓe COVID-19 fu be matinolji fu do nyauji feere malla ko foti nyaɗina ndu, 184 maynama (fu haa cakka nyauɓe je ɗon mari duuɓi ≥19); mayde 173 (94%) matinama haa kunde nyauɓe je ɗon mari pettum man nyau feere gooto.

en: Among 122,653 U.S. COVID-19 cases reported to CDC as of March 28, 2020, 7,162 (5.8%) patients had data available pertaining to underlying health conditions or potential risk factors; among these patients, higher percentages of patients with underlying conditions were admitted to the hospital and to an ICU than patients without reported underlying conditions.
ff: haa cakka nyauɓe COVID-19 122 653 haa Lesdi America je be matini haa CDC diga 28 Maars 2020, nyauɓe 7 162 (5.8%) ɗon mari matinolji je ɗon laarani nyauji feere malla ko foti nyaɗina ndu; haa kunde nyauɓe ndu, limtolji nyauɓe je ɗon mari nyau feere ɗuɗɗum neldotto haa suudu lekki malla haa ICU do nyauɓe je maray nyauji feere je ɗon matini.

en: These results are consistent with findings from China and Italy, which suggest that patients with underlying health conditions and risk factors, including, but not limited to, diabetes mellitus, hypertension, COPD, coronary artery disease, cerebrovascular disease, chronic renal disease, and smoking, might be at higher risk for severe disease or death from COVID-19.
ff: Sappinolji ɗon yahida be ko be tawi haa Cayna be Italy, je ɗon holla yo'o nyauɓe je ɗon mari nyau feere malla ko je ɗon nyaɗina ndu, be, amma naa kaanjum tan, nyau sukkar mellitus, iyam je ɗon ila be sembe, COPD, nyau lawol iyam, nyau ngaandi, nyau ɓooye je ɗon tokkita, fooɗugo, foti nyau maɓɓe nyaɗa malla bo ɓe maya.

en: This analysis was limited by small numbers and missing data because of the burden placed on reporting health departments with rapidly rising case counts, and these findings might change as additional data become available.
ff: Lartol ndu hokkay ɓibe ngam woodi kujeji pamaron be matinolji feere je wala ngam kugal caɗɗum je be watini haa do hoore geeɓeji jam ɓanndu be limgal nyauɓe je ɗon ɓesda lau, e sappinol ndu foti saanja to woodi matinolji feere yotti.

en: It is not yet known whether the severity or level of control of underlying health conditions affects the risk for severe disease associated with COVID-19.
ff: Min aanda tawon to nyaɗugo malla aynol ta'irde je laarani hala nyau memman hala do nyau je nyaɗum be COVID-19.

en: Many of these underlying health conditions are common in the United States: based on self-reported 2018 data, the prevalence of diagnosed diabetes among U.S. adults was 10.1%, and the U.S. age-adjusted prevalence of all types of heart disease (excluding hypertension without other heart disease) was 10.6% in 2017.
ff: Duɗɗum haa cakka nyauji feere ɗon waagi haa nder Lesdi America: do en joddi do matinolji je yimbe wadi be hoore maɓɓe haa 2018, limtol yahde nyauɓe je ɓon mari nyau sukkar haa cakka mauɓe Lesdi America woni 10.1%, be limtol nyauɓe duuɓi fu je mari nyau ɓernde (sna nyau iyam je ɗon ila be sembe) ɗon no 10.6% haa 2017.

en: The age-adjusted prevalence of COPD among U.S. adults is 5.9%, and in 2018, the U.S. estimated prevalence of current asthma among persons of all ages was 7.9%.
ff: Dubbi raɓɓugo nyau COPD haa kunde mauɓe Lesdi America laati 5.9 nder 100, e haa 2018, raɓɓol je laarani nyau dole haa kunde yimɓe fu woni 7.9 nder 100.

en: CDC continues to develop and update resources for persons with underlying health conditions to reduce the risk of acquiring COVID-19.
ff: CDC ɗon tokkita waddugo dabareji e larta kujeji ngam yimɓe je ɗon mari nyauji feere ngam ustugo raɓɓende COVID-19.

en: The estimated higher prevalence of these conditions among those in this early group of U.S. COVID-19 patients and the potentially higher risk for more severe disease from COVID-19 associated with the presence of underlying conditions highlight the importance of COVID-19 prevention in persons with underlying conditions.
ff: Limtol nyaɗugo nyauji ndu haa cakka ɓe'en haa nder geɓɓe aranool nyauɓe COVID-19 haa Lesdi America be raɓɓende nyauji je ɓuri nyaɗugo haa COVID-19 je ɗon hawti be nyauji feere ɗon holla naffuda aynol COVID-19 haa yimbe je ɗon mari nyauji feere.

en: The findings in this report are subject to at least six limitations.
ff: Sappinolji batakkewol ndu ɗon mari pettum man keerolji joowey e go'o.

en: First, these data are preliminary, and the analysis was limited by missing data related to the health department reporting burden associated with rapidly rising case counts and delays in completion of information requiring medical chart review; these findings might change as additional data become available.
ff: Aranol, matinolji ndu laati je aranool, e lartol ndu mari keerol ngam matinolji je ɗon laarani geeɓe jam ɓanndu ngam kugal maɓɓe je caɗɗum je ɗon hawti be limgal nyauɓe je don ɓesda lau be timminugo matinolji je yiɗi ngaɗa lartol yimɓe jam baandu je yottata lau; sappinolji ndu foti waylitta to matinolji feere wurtotto.

en: Information on underlying conditions was only available for 7,162 (5.8%) of 122,653 cases reported to CDC.
ff: Matinolji do nyauji feere ɗon no woni ngam yimbe 7 162 (5.8%) do nyauɓe 122 653 ja matinama haa CDC.

en: It cannot be assumed that those with missing information are similar to those with data on either hospitalizations or underlying health conditions.
ff: Footay numma yo'o ɓe'en je wala matinolji feere ndu ɗon naandi be feere'en je matinolji do wondugo haa cuuɗi lekki malla do nyauji feere.

en: Second, these data are subject to bias in outcome ascertainment because of short follow-up time.
ff: Ɗidabool, matinoli ndu ɗon waɗa goɗɗo mijja do ngewteji feere ngam wakkati tokkitol je ɗon rammi.

en: Some outcomes might be underestimated, and long-term outcomes cannot be assessed in this analysis.
ff: foti sappinolji feere ɗon lasbini, e sappinolji footay nasta nder lartol.

en: Third, because of the limited availability of testing in many jurisdictions during this period, this analysis is likely biased toward more severe cases, and findings might change as testing becomes more widespread.
ff: Tataɓool, ngam famɗol lartol baandu ngam umroji haa lesɗe feere be wakkati nde, lartol ndu ɗon sappina bana ɗon tedda gal nyauɓe je ɗon nyaɗi tan, e sappinolji foti waylita to lartol ɗon salla haa ko toy fu.

en: Fourth, because of the descriptive nature of these data, attack rates among persons with and without underlying health conditions could not be compared, and thus the risk difference of severe disease with COVID-19 between these groups could not be estimated.
ff: Nayaɓool, matinolji ndu ɗon sappina ko salli tan, limtol nyauɓe haa cakka yimɓe je ɗon mari malla maray nyauji feere foti foodotto, gal nden feeretirol raɓɓende nyauji nyaɗungel be COVID-19 haa kunde geeɓeji ndu footay famma.

en: Fifth, no conclusions could be drawn about underlying conditions that were not included in the case report form or about different conditions that were reported in a single, umbrella category.
ff: Jooyaɓre, footay goɗɗo hoosa hasduji do nyauji feere je nastay no nder batakkewol nyauɗo malla do waagare nyauji je ɗon matinama nder geeɓe woore tan.

en: For example, asthma and COPD were included in a chronic lung disease category.
ff: Bana sappinol, ɓe limmi nyau dole be COPD haa nder geeɓe nyau fuffu je ɗon tokkita.

en: Finally, for some underlying health conditions and risk factors, including neurologic disorders, chronic liver disease, being a current smoker, and pregnancy, few severe outcomes were reported; therefore, conclusions cannot be drawn about the risk for severe COVID-19 among persons in these groups.
ff: Timminol, ngam nyauji feere be ko foti nyaɗina, be saklere ngaandi, nyau hengre je ɗon tokkita, wondugo fooɗowo tabba, wondugo be reedu, sappinolji seeɗa tan je nyaɗum matinama; nden kadi, hasduji footay ngurta do raɓɓende COVID-19 haa kunde ummatoji haa nder geeɓeji ndu.

en: Persons in the United States with underlying health conditions appear to be at higher risk for more severe COVID-19, consistent with findings from other countries.
ff: Yimɓe haa Lesdi America be nyau feere laati bana foti nyaɗina nyau COVID-19 maɓɓe, ɗon naandi be haasduji lesɗe feere.

en: Persons with underlying health conditions who have symptoms of COVID-19, including fever, cough, or shortness of breath, should immediately contact their health care provider.
ff: Yimɓe be nyauji feere je ɗon mari mandolji nyau COVID-19, bana wulol ɓanndu, sondaaru, pofɗe bana timman, sey ngewta be feelowo jam ɓanndu maɓɓe.

en: These persons should take steps to protect themselves from COVID-19, through washing their hands; cleaning and disinfecting high-touch surfaces; and social distancing, including staying at home, avoiding crowds, gatherings, and travel, and avoiding contact with persons who are ill.
ff: Irin yimɓe ndu sey hocca yaɓɓorde ngam fadugo hoore maɓɓe ngam COVID-19, gal lallugo juɗe; laɓɓinugo baabe je juɗe ɗon memma jur; be daayol haa cakka ummatore, wondugo haa saare, accugo jonde haa cakka ummatore, kawtalji, be jaahangal, be accugo ngiddugo be yimɓe je ɗon nyauɗo.

en: Maintaining at least a 30-day supply of medication, a 2-week supply of food and other necessities, and knowledge of COVID-19 symptoms are recommended for those with underlying health conditions.
ff: Siggugo lekki je pettum man balɗe 30 haa suudu, nyamɗe be kujeji feere je asaaweji 2, aandal mandolji nyau COVID-19 ɗon feelama haa ɓe'en je ɗon mari nyau feere.

en: All persons should take steps to protect themselves from COVID-19 and to protect others.
ff: Yimɓe fu sey waɗa yaɓɓorde ngam fadugo hoore maɓɓe ngam COVID-19 e fada feere'en.

en: All persons who are ill should stay home, except to get medical care; should not go to work; and should stay away from others.
ff: Yimɓe fu je ɗon nyauɗo sey joɗɗa saare, sna to ngam larugo ɓanndu mako; yahata kugal; e sey wonda daayi be yimɓe feere.

en: This is especially important for those who work with persons with underlying conditions or who otherwise are at high risk for severe outcomes from COVID-19.
ff: Ndu laati kanduɗum haa ɓe'en je ɗon huwida be yimɓe je ɗon mari nyau feere malla bo'o je ɗon sappina mandolji nyaɗum haa COVID-19.

en: Community mitigation strategies, which aim to slow the spread of COVID-19, are important to protect all persons from COVID-19, especially persons with underlying health conditions and other persons at risk for severe COVID-19–associated disease (https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/downloads/community-mitigation-strategy.pdf).
ff: Dabareji ustugo raɓɓol ummatore, je yiɗi ustugo sankittol COVID-19, laati kanduɗum ngam fadugo yimɓe fu haa COVID-19, ɓurna bo'o yimɓe je ɗon mari nyau feere malla yimɓe je ɗon mari kujeji je foti nyaɗina nyau COVID-19 nder ɗaandu maɓɓe (https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/downloads/community-mitigation-strategy.pdf).

en: What is already known about this topic?
ff: Ko ɗon aandin timmi do ngewte ndu?

en: Published reports from China and Italy suggest that risk factors for severe COVID-19 disease include underlying health conditions, but data describing underlying health conditions among U.S. COVID-19 patients have not yet been reported.
ff: Deftereji je wurti haa Cayna be Italy ɗon feela yo'o kuje je nyaɗinatta nyau COVID-19 laarani larulaaji jam ɓandu, amma matinolji je sappinatta larulaaji jam ɓanndu haa kunde nyauɓe COVID-19 haa lesdi America wangay tawon.

en: What is added by this report?
ff: Ɗumme ɓesdi haa nder batakkewol ndu?

en: Based on preliminary U.S. data, persons with underlying health conditions such as diabetes mellitus, chronic lung disease, and cardiovascular disease, appear to be at higher risk for severe COVID-19–associated disease than persons without these conditions.
ff: Do matinolji aranool Lesdi America, yimɓe je ɗon mari nyauji feere bana nyau sukkar, nyau fuffu je ɗon tokkita, be nyauji ɓernde, laati bana foti heɓɓa nyau COVID-19 je ɗon nyaɗungel do yimɓe je maray nyauji ndu.

en: What are the implications for public health practice?
ff: Ɗumme wonni ngaɗama ngam jam ɓanndu ummatore?

en: Strategies to protect all persons and especially those with underlying health conditions, including social distancing and handwashing, should be implemented by all communities and all persons to help slow the spread of COVID-19.
ff: Dabareji ngam fadugo yimɓe fu be ɓurna ɓe'en je ɗon mari nyauji feere, be baabe haa kunde ummatore be lallugo juɗe, sey ummatoji fu be yimɓe fu ngaɗa ndu ngam ustugo sankittol COVID-19.

en: Emergence of a Novel Coronavirus (COVID-19): Protocol for Extending Surveillance Used by the Royal College of General Practitioners Research and Surveillance Centre and Public Health England
ff: Wurtol Koronaviriis je Keese (COVID-19): Dabare Yajjinugo Aynol je Royal College of Practitioners Research and Surveillance Centre and Public Health England ɗon Huwida be man

en: The Royal College of General Practitioners (RCGP) Research and Surveillance Centre (RSC) and Public Health England (PHE) have successfully worked together on the surveillance of influenza and other infectious diseases for over 50 years, including three previous pandemics.
ff: Royal College of General Practitioners (RCGP) Research and Surveillance Centre (RSC) and Public Health England (PHE) huwidi be boɗɗe haa baabal gooto do aynol ndamba malla nyauji raɓɓungel feere haa gadda 50, be nyauji duniyaru je tati ndu.

en: With the emergence of the international outbreak of the coronavirus infection (COVID-19), a UK national approach to containment has been established to test people suspected of exposure to COVID-19.
ff: Be wangol nyau koronaviriis je ɗon memma duniyaru fu (COVID-19), woodi dabare darnol haa lesɗe Inglisiya wurtini ngam lartugo ummatoji je be tammi don joɗɗidi haa wakkere COVID-19.

en: At the same time and separately, the RCGP RSC’s surveillance has been extended to monitor the temporal and geographical distribution of COVID-19 infection in the community as well as assess the effectiveness of the containment strategy.
ff: haa wakkati man bo'o e gal wakkere feere, aynol RCGP RSC ɗon juttini ngam lartugo sankittol COVID-19 be wakkati haa nder wakkere nder ummatore be lartugo to dabare darnugo ndu ɗon yaha.

en: The aims of this study are to surveil COVID-19 in both asymptomatic populations and ambulatory cases with respiratory infections, ascertain both the rate and pattern of COVID-19 spread, and assess the effectiveness of the containment policy.
ff: Ekkitol ndu yidi aynugo COVID-19 ɗiɗi fu haa ummatoji je sappinata mandolji nyau tawon be nyauɓe je ɗon waanca be nyauji pofɗe, larta ɗiɗi fu limtol be yajjol COVID-19, e larta siyasa darnol nyau ndu.

en: The RCGP RSC, a network of over 500 general practices in England, extract pseudonymized data weekly.
ff: RCGP RSC, kawtirde je mari kuɗe lartol fu 500 haa Inglisiya, ɗon mofta matinolji bila inde yimɓe nder ton haa asaweji fu.

en: This extended surveillance comprises of five components: (1) Recording in medical records of anyone suspected to have or who has been exposed to COVID-19.
ff: Aynol je ɗon yajji ndu ɗon mari kujeji joowey: (1) Bindol haa nder defteji ko moy fu je ɓe tammi mari malla je woni no haa wakkere COVID-19.

en: Computerized medical records suppliers have within a week of request created new codes to support this.
ff: Huwoɓe nastirde bindi haa nder defteji gal ordo mari haa nder asaware emmol wurtini lambaji keese ngam wallugo ndu.

en: (2) Extension of current virological surveillance and testing people with influenza-like illness or lower respiratory tract infections (LRTI)—with the caveat that people suspected to have or who have been exposed to COVID-19 should be referred to the national containment pathway and not seen in primary care.
ff: (2) Yajjinol aynol yahde viriisji jonta, be lartol yimɓe je ɗon mari nyau bana ndamba malla nyauji lawol pofɗe je les (lrtI) - be matinugo yimɓe je ɗon bana mari malla jooɗi haa wakkere je ɗon mari COVID-19 sey nella ɓe haa baabe jonde lesdi e ta wona haa aranool suklare.

en: (3) Serology sample collection across all age groups.
ff: (3) Moftol leeku neebam iyam haa cakka ummatore fu.

en: This will be an extra blood sample taken from people who are attending their general practice for a scheduled blood test.
ff: Ndu wona leeku iyam feere je hoccama haa yimɓe je ɗon wara tum haa kude lartol fu ngam jaahargal lartol iyam.

en: The 100 general practices currently undertaking annual influenza virology surveillance will be involved in the extended virological and serological surveillance.
ff: Kuɗe lartol fu 100 je ɗon ayna ndamba je viriis ngaɗi haa nder hittande nastan haa cakka aynol jaangirde viriis be neebam iyam je ɗon yajji.

en: (4) Collecting convalescent serum samples.
ff: (4) Moftol leekuje neebam iyam je ɗon do nyambittugo.

en: We have the opportunity to escalate the data extraction to twice weekly if needed.
ff: Min ɗon mari sa'a ɓesdugo wurtinol matinolje nde ɗiɗi haa nder asawere to woodi haaje.

en: Swabs and sera will be analyzed in PHE reference laboratories.
ff: Lekkuji be neebam iyam lartotto nder cuuɗi lartol PHE je saman.

en: General practice clinical system providers have introduced an emergency new set of clinical codes to support COVID-19 surveillance.
ff: Huwoɓe nder jaahargal cuuɗi lartol kuɗe lartol fu nastini jaawal do lambaji cuuɗi lartol keese ngam wallugo aynol COVID-19.

en: Additionally, practices participating in current virology surveillance are now taking samples for COVID-19 surveillance from low-risk patients presenting with LRTIs.
ff: haa ɓesdugo bo'o, kuɗe je ɗon ayna yahde jaangirde viriis jonta ɗon do hoosugo leekuji ngam aynol COVID-19 haa nyauɓe je nyaway jur je ɗon sappina LRTIs.

en: Within the first 2 weeks of setup of this surveillance, we have identified 3 cases: 1 through the new coding system, the other 2 through the extended virology sampling.
ff: haa nder arandere asawere 2 haa ɓaawo jo'inol aynol ndu, min mandi nyauji 3: 1 gal jaahargal lambugo keese, 2 gal leeku jaangirde viriis je ɗon yajji.

en: We have rapidly converted the established national RCGP RSC influenza surveillance system into one that can test the effectiveness of the COVID-19 containment policy.
ff: Min latini jaahargal aynol ndamba RCGP RSC je lesdi fu laugel do je foti larta siyasa darnol COVID-19.

en: The extended surveillance has already seen the use of new codes with 3 cases reported.
ff: Aynol je ɗon yajji ndu lari kugal lambugo keese be nyauji tati matinama timmi.

en: Rapid sharing of this protocol should enable scientific critique and shared learning.
ff: Sendol batakkewol ndu be lau mballittan ngam lortol teffoɓe e ko be nummi do man.

en: The Royal College of General Practitioners (RCGP) Research and Surveillance Centre (RSC) is a network of general practices (GPs) with a nationally representative population that provides pseudonymized data for weekly surveillance of infectious diseases.
ff: Royal College of General Practitioners (RCGP) Research be Surveillance Centre (RSC) laati bana kawtirde kuɗe lartol fu (GPs) be ummatore je ɗon woni haa nder lesdi man fu je ɗon saanja inde yimɓe haa nder matinolji nder asawere fu ngam lartol nyauji nyaɗum.

en: The disease surveillance program is commissioned by Public Health England (PHE) and covers 37 infectious diseases, including influenza.
ff: Jaahargal lartol nyau ɗon ɗowi gal Public Health England (PHE) e ɗon sukla do nyauji je ɗon raɓɓa 37, be ndamba.

en: The RCGP RSC and PHE have an established collaboration of over 50 years in influenza and respiratory disease surveillance and are now in their 53rd season of surveillance and analysis.
ff: RCGP RSC be PHE ɗon huwida diga duuɓi 50 do aynol nyau bana ndamba be nyau pofɗe e hande ɓe ɗon do 53re aynol be lartol maɓɓe.

en: The RCGP RSC extracts pseudonymized data from a nationally representative sample of over 500 urban and nonurban GPs each week covering a population of over 4 million.
ff: RCGP RSC ɗon wurtina matinolji je saanji inde nder ton haa nder leeku GPs je ɓuri 500 je woni haa berniji malla haa wuroji nder asawere fu be ummatore je ɓuri milionji 4.

en: Data from these practices are reported online in a weekly return, which includes monitoring weekly rates of influenza-like illness (ILI) and other communicable and respiratory diseases in England.
ff: Matinolji je kudeji ndu don sappini do hawoo haa asaaweji fu, je laarani aynol limtol nyauji je don naandi ndamba (ILI) be matinolji feere be nyauji pofde haa Inglisiya.

en: We also produce an annual report.
ff: Min don wurtina bo'o batakkewol hittande fu.

en: The RCGP RSC data set includes all coded data and all prescribed items including vaccine exposure.
ff: Matinolji RCGP RSC don laarani matinolji je don lambi be kujeji je laarani sappinol baatal.

en: The RCGP RSC conducts virology surveillance each influenza season, with 100 GPs participating in the 2019-2020 season (Figure 1).
ff: RCGP RSC don ayna do yahde viriisji haa kala wakkati ndamba, be 100 GPs je woni haa aynol je 2019-2020 (Foto 1).

en: These virology sampling practices are also recruited to be nationally representative (Figure 1).
ff: Leeku kude lartol yahde viriisji ndu hoccama ngam lattugo bana ekkitol lesdi fu (Foto 1).

en: GPs take nasopharyngeal swabs from persons showing acute respiratory illness within 7 days of the onset of symptoms.
ff: GPs don hoosa leeku kine malla daande haa yimbe je don mari nyau pofde je nyadum haa nder balde 7 diga fuddam mandolji nyau.

en: Nasopharyngeal swabs are taken from children younger than 5 years showing symptoms of acute bronchitis or bronchiolitis.
ff: Lekku je hoccama haa kine malla daande bikkon je yottay dubbi 5 je do holla mandolji bronchitis malla bronchiolitis duddum.

en: Additionally, nasopharyngeal samples are taken from anyone 5 years and older showing acute onset of ILI and respiratory synctial virus.
ff: Fahin bo'o, leekuji ndamba hoosama haa ko moy fu je mari dubbi 5 malla buri je don mari larulaaji ILI be viriis foofugo be sembe.

en: Swabs are tested at the PHE Respiratory Virus Unit for influenza to monitor positivity rates and circulating strains, as well as for measuring vaccine effectiveness.
ff: Leekuji lartotto haa Geebe Viriis Pofde PHE ngam aynugo nyadugo ndamba be limgal gildi je ton tara, e foondugo sembe baatal bo'o.

en: The RCGP RSC successfully conducted a pilot collecting serological samples from adults and linking them to a patient’s medical records during the 2018-2019 influenza season.
ff: RCGP RSC ngadi mofturde lekkuji yahde viriisji bana ekkitol haa bikkon e larta ndu be ko don windi haa nder deftere nyaudo haa wakkati ndamba je 2018-2019.

en: This pilot was in collaboration with the PHE Seroepidemiology Unit and added to the residual blood samples submitted to PHE by National Health Service (NHS) laboratories.
ff: Sappinol ndu don huwida be PHE Seroepidemiology Unit e besdi be leekuji iyam je neldama haa PHE gal suudu teffol Kude Jam Bandu Lesdi (NHS).

en: Serology can provide important information about background population immunity, and sentinel networks can provide a mechanism for systematic data collection and linkage to medical records and health outcomes.
ff: Lartol viriisji foti hokka matinolji kandudum do sembe ummatore je bawo, e hawtirdeji foti hokka dabare ngam hawtugo matinolji e ngartira dum haa derftere jam baandu.

en: The serology pilot has demonstrated the ability of the network to collect serology samples in adults.
ff: Sappinol viriisji holli wawande kawtirol ngam moftugo lekkuji yahde viriisji haa maube.

en: With the COVID-19 outbreak, PHE and RCGP RSC have adapted existing influenza surveillance to monitor the spread of COVID-19 in the community, and this protocol sets out the basis for that collaboration.
ff: Be wangol COVID-19, PHE be RCGP RSC wartiri aynol ndamba je aran do aynol sankittol COVID-19 haa nder ummatore, e batakkewol ndu don hollina dabare huwugo haa baabal gootel.

en: The primary national strategy for COVID-19 infection is containment, with patients who are at high risk managed via the telephone help system NHS111 and the PHE health protection teams, but the RCGP RSC surveillance is entirely separate.
ff: Aranool dabare lesdi ngam nyau COVID-19 woni darnol, be nyaube je foti nyau mabbe lata nyadungel gal dabare wallende be telefon NHS111 be geebeji fadol jam baandu PHE, amma aynol RCGP RSC laati feerejo.

en: The RCGP RSC, by extending its established work, will provide virological and serological surveillance to monitor the temporal and geographical distribution of COVID-19 infection in the community, and assess the effectiveness of the containment strategy.
ff: RCGP RSC, gal yajjinugol kugal mako je aran, ndokkan aynol do yahde viriisji be neebam iyam ngam aynugo sankitol nyau COVID-19 be wakkati man haa nder wakkere man haa nder ummatore, e larta dabare darnol nyau ngu.

en: We would not be working in isolation on this research.
ff: Footay en huwaa do wurtinol haa nder teffol ndu.

en: We will share the protocol with UK colleagues and the I-MOVE consortium who have recently obtained EU Horizon 2020 funding from the stream “Advancing knowledge for the clinical and public health response to the novel coronavirus epidemic”.
ff: Min sendan batakewol ndu be sobiraabe amin je kugal je don woni haa Lesde Inglisiya e kawtal I-MOVE je kebbi wallende EU Horizon 2020 haa "stream “Advancing knowledge for the clinical and public health response to the novel coronavirus epidemic”.

en: It is anticipated that great efficiencies in project management will result through this collaboration than that obtained from countries acting alone.
ff: Woni artama je dabareji dudum haa nder kugal wurtan gal huwidugo haa baabal gootel do lesdiji je huwata feere mabbe.

en: The aim of this study is to identify whether there is undetected community transmission of COVID-19, estimate population susceptibility, and monitor the temporal and geographical distribution of COVID-19 infection in the community.
ff: Jaangirde ndi yidi manda to woodi rabbol COVID-19 je don salla aandakke haa nder ummatore, famma yimbe hoosata dum, e ayna sankittol nyau COVI-19 haa nder ummatore be wakkati nder wakkere.

en: The objectives of this study are as follows:
ff: Nda ujaji ekkitol ndu don limti:

en: To monitor the burden of suspected COVID-19 activity in the community through primary care surveillance and clinical coding of possible COVID-19 cases referred into the containment pathway
ff: Aynugo kugal COVID-19 je don teeda do ummatore gal aranool aynol be lambugo to bana foti wowa nyaube COVID-19 je don siggi nder dabare wurtugo cakka ummatore.

en: To provide virological evidence on the presence and extent of undetected community transmission of COVID-19 and monitor positivity rates among individuals presenting ILI or acute respiratory tract infections to primary care
ff: Hokkugo sappinol viriis do wondugo be yajjugo rabbol COVID-19 je don salla suudu-suudi haa nder ummatore e aynugo limtol nyaube haa kunde yimbe je don sappina ILI malla nyauji lawol pofde haa aranool fadol.

en: To estimate baseline susceptibility to COVID-19 in the community and estimate both symptomatic and asymptomatic exposure rates in the population through seroprevalence monitoring
ff: Larugo noy ummatore jabbata COVID-19 e lara limtol be'en je don sappina mandolji nyau e be'en je sappinata ndu haa nder ummatore aynugo neebam iyam.

en: To pilot implementation of a scheme for collection of convalescent sera with antibody profiles among recovered cases of COVID-19 discharged to the community
ff: Sappinugo noy dabare mofturde neebam iyam je don mari fadoobe baandu salatta haa cakka ummatore je nyaube COVID-19 je don ruffi haa yaasi.

en: We intend to capture the following.
ff: Min ngidi hoosugo ko don sappini.

en: Clinical workload related to reports of COVID-19 using the codes created to flag cases, those being assessed and where the infection is located are excluded (Figures 2-​-44)
ff: Kude haa nder cuddi teffol lekki je laarani COVID-19 je huwidata be lamba wangini nyau bana leepol, be'en je be larti e je nyau man don wondi limmay cakka man (didolji 2 haa 44)

en: Foreign countries visited in the last 28 days
ff: Lesde dayindi je ngilli haa bawo balde 28

en: Existing codes that may have utility (Tables 1-​-3).3).
ff: Lamba je wondi je foti naffa (Tabaalji 1--3).3).

en: Many GPs and primary care teams may not realize that important relevant data can be coded.
ff: GPs be geebeji suklare aranool duddum footay famma yo'o matinolji kandudum e boddde foti lambatto.

en: There is also the potential during any pandemic to monitor the effectiveness of any transmission control measures.
ff: foti bo'o dabare aynugo dabareji aynol rabbol nyau haa wakkati.

en: Reliable coding of letters and test results that will show an infection has become either confirmed or excluded
ff: Lambugo batakkeji be jabbuye lartolji je mari amana je sappinan yo'o nyau laati tawama malla tawakke

en: The methods will follow the approach used in the current influenza surveillance system and recent serology study, and includes five components: (1) primary care clinical surveillance; (2) virological surveillance; (3) population serological surveillance; (4) convalescent sera in cases; and (5) data curation.
ff: Dabareji tokkitan siyasa je en hoosi haa nder aynol ndamba amin je jonta be jaangirde jonta do neebam iyam, e doon laarani kujeji joowey: (1) aynol suudu lekki do aranool suklare; (2) aynol viriis; (3) aynol neebam iyam ummatore; (4) neebam iyam nyaube je don nyambitti; be (5) wilugo matinolji.

en: The NHS uses the Systematized Nomenclature of Medicine Clinical Terms (SNOMED CT) system of coding, which is normally only updated twice annually.
ff: NHS don hoosi dabare lambugo Systematized Nomenclature of Medicine Clinical Terms (SNOMED CT), je lartotto no nde didi tan haa nder hittande.

en: There was added complexity as some computerized medical record (CMR) suppliers use the Read coding systems (Read clinical terms version 3 – CTv3), which is no longer updated.
ff: woodi kuje feere je besdi saatol ndu bana hokkoobe batakkeji suddi lekki gal ordoji (CMR) don huwa be Read coding systems (Read clinical terms version 3 – CTv3), je lartay fahin.

en: Additionally, there were no clinical codes to record COVID-19 in early February 2020.
ff: Fahin, wala no lamba suudu lekki ngam windugo COVID-19 haa fuddam lewru Feviriye 2020.

en: Therefore, the two main GP system suppliers added the five terms shown in Table 4 as system-wide local codes.
ff: Nden kadi, hokkoobe dabare GP je didi besdi woldeji joowey je don holli haa nder Tabaal 4 bana lambaji jaahargal je don yajji.

en: A UK emergency release of SNOMED CT concepts for COVID-19 was also subsequently made available across all CMR systems (Table 4).
ff: woodi ekkitol je Lesdi Inglisiya wurtini be jaawal ngam SNOMED CT do COVID-19 don tokkiti bo'o e don wondi haa nder jaahargalji CMR fu (Tabaal 4).

en: The intention is that these will eventually be mapped to the new SNOMED CT concepts as they become available, allowing recording of relevant data (Multimedia Appendix 1).
ff: Ndu ngam hokkugo inde haa SNOMED CT je keese to be woni taskitti, je latina bindi matinolji je kandudumkoydum (Multimedia Appendix 1).

en: The key requirements for this release were the ability to code (Table 4) a case of COVID-19, exposure to risk of infection (travel to an area where there may be a higher risk), contact with anyone infected with COVID-19, a report that a person had been tested for COVID-19, and that the disease had been excluded (likely a negative test).
ff: Emmolji kandudum ngam sappinol ndu laati lambol (Tabaal 4) nyaudo COVID-19, wondugo haa wakkere rabbol nyau (jaahangal haa wakkere je laati don halli), ngidugo be goddo je don mari COVID-19, batakkewol je don sappina yo'o woodi goddo je be larti baandu mako ngam COVID-19, e je nyau man tawakka haa nder baandu mako (bana wi'ugo gildi ndu wala).

en: In addition, practices are now able to code any foreign travel undertaken, including the ability to record visits to multiple countries (implemented February 8, 2020).
ff: haa besdugo, kude foti jonta lamba kala jaahangal je ngadotto, be dabare nastinugo ngilliji haa lesde jur (wurti haa 8 Feviriye 2020).

en: Figures 2-​-44 show the EMIS web implementation.
ff: Fotoji 2--4 don sappina wurtol daaldal teffol EMIS.

en: Currently, virology samples for influenza surveillance are accompanied by a standard request form.
ff: Jonta, leekuji yahde viriis ngam aynol ndamba don tokkiti be batakkewol emmol je aran.

en: For COVID-19, we will create a new request form that will record:
ff: Ngam COVID-19, min wurtinan ewnandu keese je limtata:

en: Date of onset of symptoms
ff: Fuddam mandolji nyau ndu

en: Diagnosis of any of the following:
ff: Lartol gootoo cakka ko don limti:

en: Acute bronchitis/bronchiolitis in those younger than five years
ff: Bronchitis/bronchiolitis je nyadungel haa be'en je yottay dubbi joowey

en: Lower respiratory tract infection (LRTI)
ff: Nyau lawol pofde je les (LRTI)

en: History of fever (Y/N); measured (Y/N); if yes, level
ff: Wulol baandu (O/K); foondi (O/K); to oho, ta'irde

en: Shortness of breath (Y/N), if measured: oxygen saturation and respiratory rate
ff: Pofde je bana daran (O/K), to foondi: hebbinol hendu be limtol pofde

en: Recent travel (Y/N); if yes, countries visited in last 14 days
ff: Jaahangal je nebbay (O/K); to oho, lesde je a ngilli haa nder balde 14 sallingo

en: Contact with a named person with confirmed COVID-19 (Y/N) with a free text comment about the level of certainty
ff: Ngidol be goddo je don mari nyau COVID-19 je a andi inde mako (O/K) be ngewte feere do goongaku wolde nde

en: These codes will be grouped ontologically into “definite”, “probable”, “possible”, and “not a case” using our standard approach to grouping codes (Table 5), which has been used previously across disease areas.
ff: Lambaji ndu wonan nder geebeji je yahatta diga “gonga”, “footi”, “footi wada”, be “wonay nyau” be dabare sappinol amin ngam lambaji geebe (Tabaal 5), je en huwidi be man haa nder wakkereji nyauji.

en: The RCGP RSC definition for ILI is shown in Multimedia Appendix 2.
ff: Ekkitol do RCGP RSC ngam ILI sappinama haa Multimedia Appendix 2.

en: Public Presentation of Data Using an Observatory and Dashboards
ff: Public Presentation of Data Using an Observatory and Dashboards

en: We will develop an observatory to present data nationally and a dashboard for feedback to practices about their data quality and collection of virology and serology samples.
ff: Min wurtinan kuje larugo ngam sappinugo matinolji haa nder lesdi fu be kuje windugo ngam ngewte yimbe do kude do daraja matinolji be mofturde leekuji yahde viriisji be neebam iyam.

en: This is based on coding described in Table 4.
ff: Ndu joddi do lambugo je don sappina haa Tabaal 4.

en: Definite case will be presented on our dashboard as “cases” of COVID-19.
ff: Nyau je gonga wonan sappinama haa do kuje windugo bana "nyauji" COVID-19.

en: Possible cases will be presented as “Under investigation” (investigating).
ff: Je foti wona nyauji sappinama bana "Do Lartol" (lartama).

en: “Not a case” will be presented as “Excluded”.
ff: "Wonay nyau" wonan sappinama as "Meedi".

en: Online data has been established within the initial few weeks in the COVID-19 Observatory (Figure 5), indicating the overall number of patients and rate per 10,000 patients of cases confirmed or under investigation, as well as where the virus is excluded.
ff: Matinolji je don do hawoo wangi haa nder arandere asaweji haa nder Larol COVID-19 (Foto 5), e don sappina limgal nyaube fu be limtol haa kunde nyaube 10 000 je don aandin malla do lartol, be wakkere je be meedi viriis.

en: We have the option to move to twice weekly surveillance reports with a scope to change this to daily reporting.
ff: Min foti waylittugo aynol batakkeji haa didi nder asawere be jaahargal saanjugo ndu haa batakkewol balde do balde.

en: We will continue virology sampling from our sentinel practices, rather than discontinuing as seasonal influenza declines.
ff: Min tokkitan be leeku yahde viriisji haa nder kude sentinel amin, do darnugo haa wakkati je ndamba don usta.

en: Additionally, we will recruit more surveillance practices.
ff: Besdugo bo'o, min hoosan kude aynol buri fahin.

en: The RCGP RSC virology practices will aim to undertake 200-300 nasopharyngeal swabs per week across the RCGP RSC sentinel network, collecting specimens across all age bands.
ff: Kude RCGP RSC do gildi yidi yoosugo ndamba je wurtata gal kine 200 haa 300 haa nder asawere fu haa nder kawtirde aynol RCGP RSC, gal moftugo ndu haa geebe bi adama fu.

en: In addition to the inclusion criteria for influenza virology surveillance (ILI, acute bronchitis/bronchiolitis), participating practices will take nasopharyngeal swab samples from any people showing acute symptoms of LRTI if the onset of symptoms is within 7 days.
ff: haa besdugo haa dabare nastinugo ngam aynol yahde viriisji ndamba (ILI, bronchitis/bronchiolitis), kude je ngadotto hoccan leekuji ndamba je kine malla daande haa kala nyaudo je don sappina mandolji nyau LRTI je nyadungel to fuddam mandolji ndu woni haa nder balde 7.

en: RCGP RSC research officers and practice liaison staff will manage practices to achieve a total national sample of 200-300 swabs per week.
ff: Ardube teffol RCGP RSC be huwobe kugal kawtal teffan dabareji ngam jukkugo lekkuji ndamba 200 haa 300 nder asawere haa nder lesdi fu.

en: This could be increased if PHE modelers require more samples.
ff: Ndu foti besda to mo je don sukli do memmugo PHE emmi leekuji feere fahin.

en: Samples from each practice would be spread across the following age groups: < 5 years, 5-17 years, 18-64 years, and 65 years and older
ff: Leekuji je hoosama haa kala kude wonan sankittama haa kunde geebeji je don sappini ndu: < dubbi 5, dubbi 5-17, dubbi 18-64, be dubbi 65 e je buri

en: Samples (swabs or serum) collected will be sent via prepaid envelopes addressed to the appropriate PHE laboratory for analysis.
ff: Leekuji (ndamba malla iyam) je moftanga neldama haa nder takardeji haa suudu lartol PHE ngam lartugo ndu.

en: All samples collected will be tested for the presence of influenza and COVID-19.
ff: Leekuji fu je don mofti wonan lartama ngam larugo ndamba be COVID-19.

en: Additionally, PHE will retrospectively test any influenza virology samples collected between early and mid-February 2020 for COVID-19.
ff: Fahin, PHE laritan bo'o lartol leekuji viriis ndamba je moftotto haa kunde fuddam be cakare Feviriye 2020 ngam COVID-19.

en: Practices will still follow the PHE protocol for COVID-19 with respect to people at risk of infection who should be signposted down the containment pathway, rather than physically attend their practice.
ff: Kude tokkitan dabare PHE COVID-19 fahin be aynugo do yimbe je foti naanga nyau man je sey lata bana mandol haa nder dabareji ustol, do wondugoo haa nder kude ndu be hoore mum.

en: Direct testing of those who attend surgery remains permitted, but we have also rolled out self-swabbing at home.
ff: Lartol ciir be'en je don walla lekkitajo nder seekkugo don jarfi, amma en meedi hoosugo lekkuji ndamba be hoore mum.

en: Summary of processes are detailed in Multimedia Appendix 3.
ff: Ramtol laahalji don limti haa Multimedia Appendix 3.

en: Everyone with an ILI or a respiratory illness who contacts a GP (eg, phones for an appointment) should be asked specifically about recent travel to China and other countries flagged in current PHE advice, or if they have had contact with other people with COVID-19.
ff: Ko moy fu be ILI malla nyau foofugo je ewni GP (bana, ewni ngam fottugo) sey emmotto to o wadi jaahangal haa Cayna be lesde je don hollitti haa do feelore PHE je jonta, malla to be joddidi be yimbe feere je don mari COVID-19.

en: If these screening enquiries are positive, the patient would be advised to not come to the practice but instead to follow the PHE flow sheet.
ff: To lartolji je be emmi don sappina nyau, sey be feela nyaudo ngam ta o wara kude amma tokka ko don wini haa do batakkewol PHE.

en: This can be by a reception or clinician staff, depending on individual practice protocol.
ff: Ndu foti wona gal huwoobe jabbol malla jam baandu, bana ko batakkewol kude goddo do sappina.

en: These calls should be coded into the GP CMR system and can be reported as part of the RCGP RSC weekly return.
ff: Ewnolji ndu sey wona haa nder jaahargal GP CMR e foti wona bana batakkewol asawere RCGP RSC.

en: We have developed training material to support this coding (Multimedia Appendix 4).
ff: Min wurtini kujeji jaanginugo ngam wallugo be lambugo ndu (Multimedia Appendix 4).

en: These include prompt cards for:
ff: Ndu don laarani karteji ngam:

en: Practice reception or triage staff: for coding of any patients calling the practice with symptoms of acute respiratory infection with a history of travel to important areas based on PHE advice
ff: Dabare jabbugo malla geebe subol: ngam mandugo nyaube je ewnatta kugal be mandolji nyau je hadata be foofugo e je be ngadi jaahangal haa wakereji je don limti haa feeloore PHE

en: Administrative staff or clinicians who code: to encourage consistent coding of results for any suspected cases, including coding of negative results for exclusion
ff: Huwoobe ardugo malla suudu lekki je don lamba: ngam sembitinugo lambugo sappinolji ngam kala nyau je don tammi, be lambugo sappinol je wala nyau ngam meedugo.

en: Practices participating in virology surveillance will opportunistically collect blood samples from patients coming into the practice for a routine blood test.
ff: Wondugo nder kude ngam aynol yahde viriis moftan leekuji iyam haa yakke feere haa nyaube je warata haa wakere kude ngam lartol iyam mabbe bana ko wowa.

en: Patients who attend their practice for a routine blood test will be asked to provide an additional sample for serology.
ff: Be emman haa nyaube je wondi haa kugal lartugo iyam be leeku feere fahin ngam lartugo gildi ndu.

en: We have conducted initial searches within the RCGP RSC database to look at the number of full blood count (FBC) results and overall rates in adults and children (Figures 6-​-9).9).
ff: Mi fuddi arandere teffolji nder sigorde matinolji RCGP RSC ngam sappinol limtol iyam (FBC) be limtol man fu haa maube be bikkon (Fotoji 6--9).9).

en: An FBC is one of the most common tests performed, and we hope this will give an approximate indication of overall numbers of blood tests performed.
ff: FBC laati bana gootoo haa cakka lartolji je don aandin, e min tammi ndu hokkan amin matinol do limtol lartolji iyam je en sallini fu.

en: The sampling rate, per 100,000 patients was highest for children 15-17 years of age and 60 year or older in adults, with the lowest rates in children 0-4 years of age and 18-29 years of age in adults (Figures 6-​-99).
ff: Limtol leekuji, haa nyaube 100 000 laati buri masin haa bikkon je don mari dubbi 15-17 be dubbi 60 malla je buri haa maube, be limto je buri lessugo haa bikkon dubbi 0-4 be dubbi 18-29 haa maube (Fotoji 6-​-99).
