en: In contrast, experts say South Korea's broad availability of testing helped reduce the spread of the novel coronavirus.
ff: haa yakke feere, aandoɓe wi'i wagaare lartolji haa South Korea walli ustugo yajjol koronaviriis keese.

en: Testing capacity, largely in private sector labs, was built up over several years by the South Korean government.
ff: Dabare lartolji, ɓurna fu haa nder cuuɗi lartolji filu, wurtama diga duuɓi ɗuɗɗum gal ngomna South Korea.

en: On 16 March, the World Health Organization called for ramping up the testing programmes as the best way to slow the advance of COVID-19 pandemic.High demand for testing due to wide spread of the virus caused backlogs of hundreds of thousands of tests at private U.S. labs, and supplies of swabs and chemical reagents became strained.
ff: haa 16 Maars, Geeɓe Jam ɓanndu Duniyaru ewni ngam yaawinugo jaahargalji lartol bana dabare kanduɗum ngam ustugo yahde nyau COVID-19. Emmolji lartolji je laati jur ngam yajjol viriis ɗayyini lartolji ujinere do ujinere haa cuuɗi lartol filu haa Lesɗe Amerika, e kujeji hoosugo leekuji be reagentji laati caɗɗum.

en: In March 2020 China reported problems with accuracy in their test kits.
ff: haa Maars 2020 Cayni matini larulaaji be amana haa nder kujeji lartol maɓɓe.

en: In the United States, the test kits developed by the CDC had "flaws;" the government then removed the bureaucratic barriers that had prevented private testing.Spain purchased test kits from Chinese firm Shenzhen Bioeasy Biotechnology Co Ltd, but found that results were inaccurate.
ff: haa Lesɗe America, kujeji lartol je Cayna wurtini gal CDC mari "keleewolji", nden kadi ngomna wurtinu keerolji umrore je ɗon no haɗa lartol gal cuuɗi lartolji je wonnay je ngomna. Spain soodi kujeji lartolji haa suudu Cayna Shenzhen Bioeasy Biotechnology Co Ltd, amma tawi yo'o sappinolji maray amana.

en: The firm explained that the incorrect results may be a result of a failure to collect samples or use the kits correctly.
ff: Suudu man holli yo sappinolji je wonday gonga ɗo foti waɗi ngam harbol haa nder hoosugo lekkuji malla huwidugo boɗɗum be kuje lartol.

en: The Spanish ministry said it will withdraw the kits that returned incorrect results, and would replace them with a different testing kit provided by Shenzhen Bioeasy.80% of test kits the Czech Republic purchased from China gave wrong results.Slovakia purchased 1.2 million test kits from China which were found to be inaccurate.
ff: Geeɓe Spaniya wi'i o wurtinan kujeji lartol je lorni sappinolji je wonay gonga fahin, e waylittan ndu be kujeji lartol feere je Shenzhen Bioeasy. 80% haa cakka kujeji lartol je Czech Republic soddi haa Cayna hokki sappinolji je wonay gonga. Slovakia soddi kujeji lartol milionre 1.2 haa Cayna je ɓe tawi sappinata gonga.

en: Prime Minister Matovič suggested these be dumped into the Danube.Ateş Kara of the Turkish Health Ministry said the test kits Turkey purchased from China had a "high error rate" and did not "put them into use."The UK purchased 3.5 million test kits from China but in early April 2020 announced these were not usable.
ff: Arduɗo Arduɓe Matovič feeli yo'o sey sakina ndu haa nder maliya Danube. Ateş Kara je Geeɓe Jam ɓanndu Turki wi'i kujeji lartol je Turki soddi haa Cayna ɗon mari "limtol harbol jur" e "huwiday be man". "Lesɗe Inglisiya soddi kujeji lartol milionji 3.5 haa Cayna amma haa fuɗɗam Aviiril matini yo'o ɓe naffata sam

en: Testing, followed with quarantine of those who tested positive and tracing of those with whom the SARS-CoV-2 positive people had had contact, resulted in positive outcomes.
ff: Lartolji, tokkiti be wattugo yimɓe je tawama mari nyau ndu haa sera e teffugo ɓe'en je joɗɗidi malla ngidi be nyauɓe SARS-CoV-2, sappini no naffuda.

en: Researchers working in the Italian town of Vò, the site of the first COVID-19 death in Italy, conducted two rounds of testing on the entire population of about 3,400 people, about ten days apart.
ff: Teffoɓe je huwata haa nder berniwol Italy je mbiyotto Vò, wakere aranool wade COVID-19 haa Italy, sallini geeɓeji lartol haa do ummatore yimɓe 3 400 deydey nder balɗe sappo.

en: About half the people testing positive had no symptoms, and all discovered cases were quarantined.
ff: Yimɓe ɓadi reeta je larti bana mari nyau maray no mondolji, e nyauɓe fu je tawama ɓe wati ɓe haa sera.

en: With travel to the commune restricted, this eliminated new infections completely.
ff: Be jaahangal haa nder berniwol ɗon haɗi, ndu darni raɓɓolji nyau keese.

en: With aggressive contact tracing, inbound travel restrictions, testing, and quarantining, the 2020 coronavirus pandemic in Singapore has proceeded much more slowly than in other developed countries, but without extreme restrictions like forced closure of restaurants and retail establishments.
ff: Be lortol haa yimɓe je ngidi be nyauɓe, darnol jaahangal haa ɓe'en je nastatta, lartolji, wattugo yimɓe haa sera, nyau duniyaru koronaviriis 2020 haa Singapore ɗon no ɓuri dayyugo be yahde do haa nder lesɗi je ɗon riski, amma bila haɗolji nyaɗum bana maɓɓol suudu nyamɗe be sembe malla cuuɗi sippitolji.

en: Many events have been cancelled, and Singapore did start advising residents to stay at home on 28 March, but schools reopened on time after holiday break on 23 March.
ff: Kujeji jur darnotto, e Singapore fuɗɗi feelugo ummatore wonda haa saare haa 28 Maars, amma jaangirdeji maɓɓitama be wakkati haa ɓaawo siwtare 23 Maars.

en: Several other countries have also managed the pandemic with aggressive contact tracing, inbound travel restrictions, testing, and quarantining, but with less aggressive lock-downs, such as Iceland and South Korea.
ff: Lesɗe feere ɗuɗɗum ayni nyau duniyaru ndu gal lortugo haa yimɓe be wondi be nyauɓe, haɗol jaahangal nastugo, lartolji, be wattugo yimɓe haa sera, amma be dabareji wondugo saare je saɗɗay masin bana Iceland be Korea.

en: A statistical study has found that countries that have tested more, relative to the number of deaths, have much lower case fatality rates, probably because these countries are better able to detect those with only mild or no symptoms.
ff: Ekkitol limtol sappini yo'o lesɗe je larti jur, do ko laarani limgal yimɓe je maayi, limtol mayde ɓuri lessugo, temma ngam lesɗe nde ɗon no taski masin ngam fammugo mandolji je saɗɗay malla je wala sam.

en: WHO recommends that countries that do not have testing capacity and national laboratories with limited experience on COVID-19 send their first five positives and the first ten negative COVID-19 samples to one of the 16 WHO reference laboratories for confirmatory testing.
ff: WHO feeli yo'o lesɗe je maray dabare lartol be cuuɗi lartolji lesdi je maray aandalji jur do COVID-19 nella arandere lekkuji joowey je larti bana mari nyau COVID-19 be lekkuji sappo bana je larti maray nyau COVID-19 haa gooto cakka cuuɗi lartol 16 je WHO bana sappinol ngam aanditinugo lartol ndu.

en: Out of the 16 reference laboratories, 7 are in Asia, 5 in Europe, 2 in Africa, 1 in North America and 1 in Australia.
ff: haa cakka cuuɗi lartolji 16 ndu, 7 woni haa Asia, 5 haa Erop, 2 haa Afirika, 1 haa Woila America be 1 haa Australia.

en: In the following chart, the column “Positive as % of tests” is influenced by the country's testing policy.
ff: haa nder tabaal je tokkata ndu, geeɓe "Mari bana % lartolji" memmama gal siyasa lesdi do lartolji.

en: A country that only tests people admitted to hospitals will have a higher positive as % of tests than a country that tests all citizens, whether or not they are showing symptoms, other things being equal.
ff: Lesdi je ɗon larta yimɓe je neldama haa suudu lekki tan ɗon mari limgal yimɓe je mari nyau ɓuri ngam % lartolji do lesdi je ɗon larta ummatore mako fu, ko to ɓe ɗon sappina malla sappinata mandolji, kujeji feere laati kalkal.

en: Hand washing (or handwashing), also known as hand hygiene, is the act of cleaning one's hands for the purpose of removing soil, grease, microorganisms, or other unwanted substances.
ff: Lallugo juɗe, je mbiyotto bana laɓɓinol juɗe, laati bana lottugo juɗe mum ngam ittugo lesdi, neebam, coolaaje, malla kujeji feere je wala naffuda.

en: Hand washing with soap consistently at certain "critical moments" during the day prevents the spread of many diseases, for example diarrhoea and cholera, which are transmitted through fecal–oral route.
ff: Lallugo juɗe sabulu haa "wakkati fu" haa nder nyalade ustan sankittol nyauji jur, bana caarol be koleera, je ɗon salla gal buuwe haa hunduko.

en: People can also become infected with respiratory diseases such as influenza or the common cold, for example, if they do not wash their hands before touching their eyes, nose, or mouth (i.e., mucous membranes).
ff: Yimɓe foti nanga nyau be nyauji pofɗe bana ndamba malla ndamba meere, to bana ɓe lallay juɗe maɓɓe hiddeko memmugo gite, kine malla hunduko maɓɓe (bana wi'ugo baabal baandu je ɗon ɗiggi).

en: The five critical moments during the day where washing hands with soap is important include: before and after defecation, after cleaning a child's bottom or changing nappies, before feeding a child, before eating and before and after preparing food or handling raw meat, fish, or poultry.
ff: wakkati kanduɗum joowey haa nder balɗe je mari haaje lallugo juɗe be sabulu laati kanduɗum : hiddeko e haa ɓaawo buwugo, haa ɓaawo lallugo buwe ɓingel malla saanjugo buutal, hiddeko nyammugo e haa ɓaawo deffugo nyamdu malla memmugo kuusel, liɗɗi, malla goortoɗe.

en: If water and soap are not available, hands can be cleaned with ash.The World Health Organization recommends washing hands:
ff: To ndiyam be sabulu wala, foti on laɓɓina juɗe mon be ndoondi. Geeɓe Jam ɓanndu ɗon feela lallugo juɗe:

en: Before, during, and after preparing food.
ff: Hiddeko, haa yakke, haa ɓaawo deffugo nyamdu.

en: Before and after caring for a sick person.
ff: Hiddeko e haa ɓaawo suklugo do nyauɗo.

en: After changing the diapers or cleaning up a child who has used the toilet.
ff: haa ɓaawo saanjugo buutal malla lallugo ɓingel je ɓuuwi.

en: After blowing your nose, coughing or sneezing.
ff: haa ɓaawo a fuffu kine, a sondi malla ɓisli.

en: After touching animal, animal feed, or animal waste.
ff: haa ɓaawo a memmi daaba, nyammini daaba, malla buuwe daabaji.

en: Medical hand hygiene refers to hygiene practices related to medical procedures.
ff: Laɓɓinol juɗe laarani dabareji laahalji jam ɓanndu.

en: Hand washing before administering medicine or medical care can prevent or minimize the spread of disease.
ff: Lallugo juɗe hiddeko hokkugo lekki malla suklugo do nyauɗo foti darna malla usta sankittol nyau.

en: The main medical purpose of washing hands is to cleanse the hands of pathogens (bacteria, viruses, or other microorganisms that can cause disease) and chemicals which can cause harm or diseases.
ff: Lallugo juɗe laati kanduɗum ndu ngam ɗon laɓɓina juɗe gal ittugo gilɗi nyau (bacteriyaji, viriisji, malla coolaaje je foti hokka nyau) be kujeji feere je foti nawna malla hokka nyauji.

en: This is especially important for people who handle food or work in the medical field, but also an important practice for the general public.
ff: Ndu laati kanduɗum masin haa yimɓe je memmata nyamdu malla ɗon huwa haa nder wakkere jam ɓanndu, amma bo'o laati kuje wonde haa ummatore fu.

en: Hand washing has many health benefits, including minimizing the spread of influenza, coronavirus, and other infectious diseases; preventing infectious causes of diarrhea; decreasing respiratory infections;
ff: Lallugo juɗe ɗon mari ribaaji ɗuɗɗum, bana darnugo sankittol ndamba, koronaviriis, be nyauji je ɗon raɓɓa feere; aynugo ngam raɓɓugo caarol; ustugo nyauji pofɗe;

en: and reducing infant mortality rate at home birth deliveries.
ff: be ustugo limtol mayde ɓikkon je ɓe danyi haa saare.

en: A 2013 study showed that improved hand washing practices may lead to small improvements in the length growth in children under five years of age.
ff: Ekkitol feere haa 2013 sappini yo'o wawende be lallugo juɗe foti ngada kujeji boɗɗe haa nder maunugo ɓikkon je yottay duuɓi joowey.

en: In developing countries, childhood mortality rates related to respiratory and diarrheal diseases can be reduced by introducing simple behavioral changes, such as hand washing with soap.
ff: haa lesɗe je ɗon laffi, limtol mayde ɓikkon je laarani nyauji pofɗe be caarol foti usta gal nastinugo saanjol gikku, bana lallugo juɗe be sabulu.

en: This simple action can reduce the rate of mortality from these diseases by almost 50%.
ff: Kuje pettum ndu foti usta limtol mayde ngam nyauji ndu be 50%.

en: Interventions that promote hand washing can reduce diarrhoea episodes by about a third, and this is comparable to providing clean water in low income areas.
ff: Dabareji je yardi lallugo juɗe foti usta caarolji nder tati, ndu laati kalkal bana hokkugo ndiyam njaram je laɓnde haa wakkere je yimɓe ɗon laffi.

en: 48% of reductions in diarrhoea episodes can be associated with hand washing with soap.Hand washing with soap is the single most effective and inexpensive way to prevent diarrhea and acute respiratory infections (ARI), as automatic behavior performed in homes, schools, and communities worldwide.
ff: 48% ustolji be caarolji foti hawtirida be lallugo juɗe be sabulu. Lallugo juɗe be sabulu laati dabare je ɓuri naffugo e je lessi saɗugo ngamm aynugo nangugo caarol be nyauji pofɗe nyaɗum (ARI), bana gikku je en ngaɗatta haa saare, cuuɗi jaangirde, be ummatoji haa nder duniyaru fu.

en: Pneumonia, a major ARI, is the number one cause of mortality among children under five years old, taking the lives of an estimated 1.8 million children per year.
ff: Pneumonia, nyau ARI mmaungel, laati aranol nyau je ɗon mbarda ɓikkon je maray duuɓi joowey jur, je ɗon mbara ɓikkon waɗan milionre 1.8 haa hittande fu.

en: Diarrhea and pneumonia together account for almost 3.5 million child deaths annually.
ff: Caarol be pneumonia hawti fu ɗon mbarda ɓikkon milionji 3.5 haa hittande fu.

en: According to UNICEF, turning hand washing with soap before eating and after using the toilet into an ingrained habit can save more lives than any single vaccine or medical intervention, cutting deaths from diarrhea by almost half and deaths from acute respiratory infections by one-quarter.
ff: haa limtol UNICEF, wartirugo lallugo juɗe be sabulu hiddeko nyammugo malla haa ɓawu wurtol gaɗɗa suudu haa nder gikku amin foti hisna yonki jur do baatal malla lekki je en foti hoosa, ustan mayde ngam caarol be reeta e mayde ngam nyau pofɗe be nay.

en: Hand washing is usually integrated together with other sanitation interventions as part of water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH) programmes.
ff: Lallugo juɗe ɓurna fu ɗon yahida be dabbareji jam ɓanndu feere bana jaahargalji ndiyam, laɓɓinol be laɓnde (WASH).

en: Hand washing also protects against impetigo which is transmitted through direct physical contact.
ff: Lallugo juɗe bo'o ɗon fada ngam tarzagire je sallinama gal ngidol ɓanndu.

en: A small detrimental effect of hand washing is that frequent hand washing can lead to skin damage due to drying of the skin.
ff: Ko foti sarga seeɗa bo'o laati yo'o lallugo juɗe haa wakkati fu foti ɓoora laaral ɓanndu ngam ɗon yori.

en: A 2012 Danish study found that excessive hand washing can lead to an itchy, flaky skin condition known as hand eczema or hand dermatitis, which is especially common among health-care workers.
ff: Ekkitol Danish en feere haa 2012 sappini yo'o lallugo juɗe jur foti nyaanyina ɓanndu je ewnatto bana eczema malla dermatis jungo, je ɗon woni jur haa huwoɓe do jam ɓanndu.

en: Too frequent hand washing is also seen as one of the symptoms of obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD).
ff: Lallugo juɗe tum laati bana obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD).

en: There are five critical times during the day where washing hands with soap is important to reduce fecal-oral transmission of disease: after using the bathroom (urination, defecation), after cleaning a child's bottom (changing nappies), before feeding a child, before eating and before/after preparing food or handling raw meat, fish, or poultry.
ff: woodi wakkati joowey je kanduɗum ngam lallugo juɗe be sabulu naffan ngam ustugo sallinol nyau diga buuwe haa hunduko: haa wurtol gaɗɗa suudu (buuwe, siile), haa ɓaawo lallugo buwe ɓingel (saanjugo buutal), hiddeko nyamnugo ɓingel, hiddeko nyammugo/haa ɓaawo deffugo nyamdu malla memmugo kuusel je deffaka, liiɗi malla goortoɗe.

en: Other occasions when correct handwashing technique should be practiced in order to prevent the transmission of disease include before and after treating a cut or wound; after sneezing, coughing, or blowing your nose; after touching animal waste or handling animals; and after touching garbage.
ff: wakkatiji feere je dabare lallugo juɗe naffan ngam ayugo sallinol nyau feere laarani hiddeko malla haa ɓaawo suklugo do hudure; haa ɓaawo ɓislol, sondaaru, malla foofugo kine; haa ɓaawo memmugo buuwe daabaji malla memmugo daaba; e haa ɓaawo memmugo cuuɗol.

en: In many countries, there is a low rate of hand washing with soap.
ff: haa nder lesɗe jur, limtol yimɓe je ɗon lalla juɗe be sabulu ɗon lessi.

en: A study of hand washing in 54 countries in 2015 found that on average, 38.7% of households practiced hand washing with soap.A 2014 study showed that Saudi Arabia had the highest rate of 97 percent; the United States near the middle with 77 percent; and China with the lowest rate of 23 percent.Several behaviour change methodologies now exist to increase uptake of the behaviour of hand washing with soap at the critical times.Group hand washing for school children at set times of the day is one option in developing countries to engrain hand washing in children's behaviors.
ff: Ekkitol do lallugo juɗe haa nder lesɗe 54 haa 2015 sappini yo'o, 38.7% calaaje ɗon lalla juɗe maɓɓe be sabulu. Ekkitol feere haa 2014 sappini yo'o Saudi Arabiya mari limtol je ɓuri fu be 97%; Lesɗe America ɓadi haa cakare be 77%; Cayna be je ɓuri lessugo 23%. Dabareji saanjol gikkuji haande ɗon ɓesda ngam hoccugo gikku lallugo juɗe be sabulu haa wakkati feere je laati kanduɗum. Geeɓe lallol juɗe ɓikkon jaangirde haa wakkati je ɗon aandin haa nder balɗe laati bana dabare haa lesɗe je ɗon laffi ngam nastinugo gikku lallol juɗe haa nder hakkilo ɓikkon.

en: The "Essential Health Care Program" implemented by the Department of Education in the Philippines is an example of at scale action to promote children's health and education.
ff: Essential Health Care Program je Geeɓe jaangirde wurtini haa Filipiya laati bana sappinol dabare hokkugo daraja haa jam ɓandu e aandal ɓikkon.

en: Deworming twice a year, supplemented with washing hands daily with soap, brushing teeth daily with fluoride, is at the core of this national program.
ff: Mbarugo gilɗi nde ɗiɗi nder hittande be sabulu, yiggugo ni'e ko weeti fu be fluoride, woni haa cakare jaahargal lesdi.

en: It has also been successfully implemented in Indonesia.
ff: Hoccama bo'o be boɗɗe haa Indonesia.

en: Removal of microorganisms from skin is enhanced by the addition of soaps or detergents to water.
ff: Ittugo coolaaje do ɓanndu waɗɗotto gal ɓesdugo sabuluji malla ndiyam laɓɓinugo.

en: The main action of soaps and detergents is to reduce barriers to solution, and increase solubility.
ff: Aranool kugal sabuluji be ndiyam laɓɓinugo naffan ngam ustugo keleewolji dabare, e ɓesda sofnol.

en: Water alone is an inefficient skin cleanser because fats and proteins, which are components of organic soil, are not readily dissolved in water.
ff: Ndiyam feere majuum laati bana lalloowo ɓanndu je maray sembe ngam ɓelere be proteinji, laati kujeji je ummi lesdi, footay ndiyam meere itta ɓe.

en: Cleansing is, however, aided by a reasonable flow of water..
ff: Laɓɓinugo sey, bo'o, mballotto be ndiyam je ɗon ila boɗɗum.

en: Solid soap, because of its reusable nature, may hold bacteria acquired from previous uses.
ff: Sabulu cattuɗum, ngam foti huwida be man fahin, foti mara bacteriyaji je joddi do ton haa yakke lallol je salli.

en: A small number of studies which have looked at the bacterial transfer from contaminated solid soap have concluded transfer is unlikely as the bacteria are rinsed off with the foam.
ff: Ekkitolji seeɗa je jaangi sallinol bacteriyaji diga sabulu je cattungel sappini sallinol footay salla ngam bacteriyaji ndu dilliran be nguffu ndu.

en: The CDC still states "liquid soap with hands-free controls for dispensing is preferable".
ff: CDC ɗon mbi'a fahin bo'o "sabulu ndiyam-ndiyam je jungo memmata haa sankitol ndika".

en: Antibacterial soaps have been heavily promoted to a health-conscious public.
ff: Sabulu je mbardatta bacteriyaji ɗon feelama haa ummatore je ɗon numma do jam ɓanndu maɓɓe.

en: To date, there is no evidence that using recommended antiseptics or disinfectants selects for antibiotic-resistant organisms in nature.
ff: haa jonta, wala sappinol je hollatta yo'o huwidugo be antiseptikji malla mbarooɓe gilɗi ɗon suɓɓa ɓaali je ɗon caɗɗungel haa antibiotikji.

en: However, antibacterial soaps contain common antibacterial agents such as triclosan, which has an extensive list of resistant strains of organisms.
ff: Amma, sabuluji je mbardatta bacteriyaji ɗon mari kujeji mbardugo bacteriyaji bana triclosan, je ɗon mari limgal kuje mbardol gilɗi jur.

en: So, even if antibiotic resistant strains aren't selected for by antibacterial soaps, they might not be as effective as they are marketed to be.
ff: Nden kadi, ko to gilɗi je ɗon nyaɗi haa antiotikji suɓɓay gal sabuluji je mbardatta bacteriyaji, footay be mara sembe bana ko ɗon tindini haa nder lumo maɓɓe.

en: Besides the surfactant and skin-protecting agent, the sophisticated formulations may contain acids (acetic acid, ascorbic acid, lactic acid) as pH regulator, antimicrobially active benzoic acid and further skin conditioners (aloe vera, vitamins, menthol, plant extracts).A comprehensive analysis from the University of Oregon School of Public Health indicated that plain soaps are as effective as consumer-grade anti-bacterial soaps containing triclosan in preventing illness and removing bacteria from the hands.
ff: Ngam ɓesdugo haa surfactan be kuje fadugo laaral ɓanndu, hawtirde kujeji foti malra acidji (acetic acid, ascorbic acid, lactic acid) bana mo'itinoowo PH, benzoic acid je mbardatta viriisji be kujeji e fadol ɓanndu (aloe vera, vitaminji, mentholaasi, neeɓam lekki). Lartolji University of Oregon School of Public Health sappini yo'o sabulu meere ɗon mari semɓe gooto be sabuluji je ɓe ɗon hollina soddooɓe haa lumo je ɗon mari triclosan ngam aynugol do nyauji e ittugo bacteryaji haa do juɗe.

en: Hot water that is comfortable for washing hands is not hot enough to kill bacteria.
ff: Ndiyam gulɗam je wondi kanɗuɗum ngam lallugo juɗe wullay masitin haa mbara bacteriyaji.

en: Bacteria grow much faster at body temperature (37 °C).
ff: Bacteriyaji ɗon nufta law be wullol ɓanndu (37 °C).

en: However, warm, soapy water is more effective than cold, soapy water at removing natural oils which hold soils and bacteria.
ff: Amma, ndiyam gulɗum be sabulu ɓuri naffuda do ndiyam peewɗam ngam ittugo neebam ɓanndu je ɗon jogga cuddi be bacteriyaji.

en: Contrary to popular belief however, scientific studies have shown that using warm water has no effect on reducing the microbial load on hands.
ff: naa bana ko ummatore ɗon tammi, ekkitolji aandooɓe holli yo'o lallugo juɗe be ndiyam gulɗam walla naffuda ngam ustugo gilɗiji do juɗe.

en: A hand sanitizer or hand antiseptic is a non-water-based hand hygiene agent.
ff: Kuje laɓɓinugo jungo malla antiseptik jungo laati kuje laɓɓinugo juɗe amma wonay bana ndiyam.

en: In the late 1990s and early part of the 21st century, alcohol rub non-water-based hand hygiene agents (also known as alcohol-based hand rubs, antiseptic hand rubs, or hand sanitizers) began to gain popularity.
ff: haa ragare 1990 be fuɗɗam hittande temere 21, kuje laɓɓinugo juɗe be alkol e je wala ndiyam haa ton (je mbiyotto bo'o kuje yiggugo juɗe be alkol, kuje yiggugo juɗe antiseptik, malla kuje laɓɓinugo juɗe) fuɗɗi wangugo be sembe.

en: Most are based on isopropyl alcohol or ethanol formulated together with a thickening agent such as Carbomer (polymer of acrylic acid) into a gel, or a humectant such as glycerin into a liquid, or foam for ease of use and to decrease the drying effect of the alcohol.
ff: Ɓurna fu ɗon wondi do alkol isopropyl malla ethanol je hawtama be kuje tekkinugo bana Carbomer (polymer acrylic acid) do gel, malla kuje sofnugo bana glycerin do ndiyam, malla nguffu ngam heɓɓa huwa be man bila saɗirma be ustugo ko bana alkol ɗon yorina jungo.

en: Adding diluted hydrogen-peroxide increases further the antimicrobial activity.Hand sanitizers containing a minimum of 60 to 95% alcohol are efficient germ killers.
ff: Ɓesdugo hydrogen-peroxide je ɗon nattini ɗon ɓesda kugal ngel ngam mbardugo gilɗiji. Kuje leɓɓinugo juɗe je ɗon mari alkol 60 haa 95% ɗon naffa jur ngam mbardugo gilɗi nyau.

en: Alcohol rub sanitizers kill bacteria, multi-drug resistant bacteria (MRSA and VRE), tuberculosis, and some viruses (including HIV, herpes, RSV, rhinovirus, vaccinia, influenza, and hepatitis) and fungi.
ff: Kuje laɓɓinugo juɗe be alkol ɗon mbara bacteriyaji, bacteriya je ɗon mari sembe jur (MRSA be VRE), nyau sondaaru, be viriisji feere (bana HIV, herpes, RSV, viriis kine, vaccinia, ndamba, be nyau hengre) be fungi.

en: Alcohol rub sanitizers containing 70% alcohol kill 99.97% (3.5 log reduction, similar to 35 decibel reduction) of the bacteria on hands 30 seconds after application and 99.99% to 99.999% (4 to 5 log reduction) of the bacteria on hands 1 minute after application.Hand sanitizers are most effective against bacteria and less effective against some viruses.
ff: Kuje laɓɓinugo juɗe be alkol je ɗon mari 70% alkol mbaran 99.97% (ustol log 3.5, bana ustol decibel 35) bacteriyaji do juɗe haa nder sekonji 30 haa ɓaawo yiggugo ndu be 99.99 haa 99.999% (ustol log 4 haa 5) bacteriyaji do juɗe minti 1 haa ɓaawo yiggugo ndu. Kuje laɓɓinugo juɗe ɓuri naffugo ngam bacteriyaji e lessi naffugo ngam viriisji feere.

en: Alcohol-based hand sanitizers are almost entirely ineffective against norovirus (or Norwalk) type viruses, the most common cause of contagious gastroenteritis.Enough hand antiseptic or alcohol rub must be used to thoroughly wet or cover both hands.
ff: Kuje laɓɓinugo juɗe be alkol ɗon ɓurna wala sembe do irin viriis kine (malla Norwalk), je ɗon ɓurna andi bana kanjuum on hokkata nyau lawol pofɗe. Kuje laɓɓinol juɗe be antiseptik malla be alkol sey wonda deydey ngam heɓɓa sofna jungo e sudda juɗe ɗiɗi fu.

en: The front and back of both hands and between and the ends of all fingers are rubbed for approximately 30 seconds until the liquid, foam or gel is dry.
ff: Yeeso be ɓaawo juɗe be cakka be timminol kooli'en fu sey suddama nder sekonji 30 haa ndiyam man, nguffu malla gel majja.

en: Finger tips must be washed well too, rubbing them in both palms.The US Center for Disease Control and Prevention recommends hand washing over hand sanitizer rubs, particularly when hands are visibly dirty.
ff: Timminol kooli'en sey lallotto boɗɗum fu, gal yiggugo ɓe be juɗe ɗiɗi fu. Ɗowirɗe Aynol e Lartol Nyau Lesɗe America ɗon feela lallugo juɗe do waɗɗugo kuje laɓɓinugo juɗe, ɓurna to juɗe ɗon lara bana mari cuddi.

en: The increasing use of these agents is based on their ease of use and rapid killing activity against micro-organisms; however, they should not serve as a replacement for proper hand washing unless soap and water are unavailable.
ff: Huwidugo je ɗon ɓesda be kujeji ndu wondi ngam kooyɗum huwugo be man e ɗon mbarda gilɗiji law; amma, footay lata bana dabare lottugo jungo sna to sabulu be ndiyam wala.

en: Frequent use of alcohol-based hand sanitizers can cause dry skin unless emollients and/or skin moisturizers are added to the formula.
ff: Huwugo haa wakkati fu be kuje laɓɓinugo juɗe be alkol foti yorina laaral ɓanndu sna to kuje ɗigginugo ɓesdatto haa nder hawtirde man.

en: The drying effect of alcohol can be reduced or eliminated by adding glycerin and/or other emollients to the formula.
ff: Yornugo laaral ɓanndu alkol foti ustama malla darnama gal ɓesdugo glycerin e/malla kujeji ɗigginugo feere haa nder hawtirde man.

en: In clinical trials, alcohol-based hand sanitizers containing emollients caused substantially less skin irritation and dryness than soaps or antimicrobial detergents.
ff: Lartolji haa nder suudu teffol, sappini yo'o kuje laɓɓinugo juɗe je ɗon mari kuje ɗigginugo nder ton nyorinatta juɗe do sabulu malla kuje lottugo.

en: Allergic contact dermatitis, contact urticaria syndrome or hypersensitivity to alcohol or additives present in alcohol hand rubs rarely occur.
ff: Allergic contact dermatitis, nyau contact urticaria malla hypersensitivity haa alkol malla kujeji ɓesdugo je woni haa nder kuje laɓɓinugo juɗe be alkol ɗon yotta ndego-ndego.

en: The lower tendency to induce irritant contact dermatitis became an attraction as compared to soap and water hand washing.
ff: Dabare ustol nastinol irritant contact dermatitis laati bana ewnandu to foondi lallugo juɗe be sabulu be ndiyam.

en: Despite their effectiveness, non-water agents do not cleanse the hands of organic material, but simply disinfect them.
ff: Ko to semɓe maɓɓe ɗon, kujeji laɓɓinugo juɗe footay lalla cuddi haa do juɗe, amma ɗon mbara gilɗi tan.

en: It is for this reason that hand sanitizers are not as effective as soap and water at preventing the spread of many pathogens, since the pathogens still remain on the hands.
ff: Ngam uja ndu kujeji laɓɓinugo juɗe maray sembe je ɓuratta sabulu be ndiyam ngam aynol sankittol nyauji jur, ngam nyauji ɗon woni fahin haa do juɗe.

en: Alcohol-free hand sanitizer efficacy is heavily dependent on the ingredients and formulation, and historically has significantly under-performed alcohol and alcohol rubs.
ff: Sembe kuje laɓɓinol jungo je maray alkol jooɗi do ko ɗon hawti haa ton, a tariya ɗon sappina amin yo'o jokkay sembe kuje laɓɓinugo je ɗon mari alkol.

en: More recently, formulations that use benzalkonium chloride have been shown to have persistent and cumulative antimicrobial activity after application, unlike alcohol, which has been shown to decrease in efficacy after repeated use, probably due to progressive adverse skin reactions.
ff: Be ɓaawo ndu, dabare feere je ɗon mari benzalkonium chloride holli yo'o mari sembe je ɗon neɓɓa e ɗon hawta haa ɓaawo huwidugo be man, naa bana alkol, je ɗon sappina ustol sembe maaɗa haa ɓaawo tokkitol huwidugo be man ngam jabbuye laaral ɓandu.

en: Many people in low-income communities cannot afford soap and use ash or soil instead.
ff: Yimɓe jur haa nder ummatoji je ɗon laffi footay heɓɓa sabulu e ɗon huwa be ndoondi be lesdi.

en: Ash or soil may be more effective than water alone, but may be less effective than soap.
ff: Ndoondi malla lesdi foti ɓura ndiyam feere mako, amma foti jokkata sabulu.

en: One concern is that if the soil or ash is contaminated with microorganisms it may increase the spread of disease rather than decrease it.
ff: Saɗirma feere woni to bana ndoondi malla lesdi ɗon mari gilɗi timmi foti ɓesda sankittol nyau do ustugo ndu.

en: Like soap, ash is also a disinfecting agent because in contact with water, it forms an alkaline solution.
ff: Bana sabulu, ndoondi woni kuje mbardugo gilɗi ngam to ɗon hawti be ndiyam, latan bana kilbu.

en: WHO recommended ash or sand as alternative to soap when soap is not available.
ff: WHO feeli ndoondi be njaarenji to bana sabulu walla.

en: Correct handwashing technique recommended by the US Centers for Disease Control for prevention of transmission of disease includes the following steps:
ff: Dabare lallugo juɗe je Ɗowirɗe Aynol e Lartol sallinol Nyau haa Lesɗe America ɗon feela yaɓɓordeji je ɗon limti ndu:

en: Wet hands with warm or cold running water.
ff: Sofne juɗe be ndiyam gulɗam malla peewɗam je ɗon ila.

en: Running water is recommended because standing basins may be contaminated, while the temperature of the water does not seem to make a difference.
ff: Ndiyam je ɗon ila feelama ngam tassawo je ɗon joggi ndiyam foti mara nyau timmi, fahin bo'o wullol ndiyam footay saanja kuje feere .

en: Lather hands by rubbing them with a generous amount of soap, including the backs of hands, between fingers, and under nails.
ff: Yigge juɗe be sabulu seedɗa ngam haa nguffu wurta, be ɓaawo juɗe, cakka koli'en, be nder peɗɗeeli fu.

en: Soap lifts germs from the skin, and studies show that people tend to wash their hands more thoroughly when soap is used rather than water alone.
ff: Sabulu ɗon itta gilɗiji do laaral ɓanndu, e ekkitolji ɗon sappina yo'o yimɓe yardi lallugo juɗe maɓɓe to sabulu ɗon do ko be ndiyam cookkum.

en: Scrub for at least 20 seconds.
ff: Yigge nder segonji 20 pettum man.

en: Scrubbing creates friction, which helps remove germs from skin, and scrubbing for longer periods removes more germs.
ff: Yiggugo ɗo hawta juɗe, ko ɗon itta gilɗiji do ɓanndu e yiggugo nde jur wurtinan gilɗiji ɗuɗɗum bo'o.

en: Rinse well under running water.
ff: Lallitu be ndiyam je illata.

en: Rinsing in a basin can recontaminate hands.
ff: Lattitugo nder tassawu foti juɗe hoosita gilɗiji fahin.

en: Dry with a clean towel or allow to air dry.
ff: Yorine be limse laɓɗe malla be hendu.

en: Wet and moist hands are more easily recontaminated.The most commonly missed areas are the thumb, the wrist, the areas between the fingers, and under fingernails.
ff: Juɗe je on sofni foti hoositta gilɗi law fahin. Wakkereji je yimɓe lallatta boɗɗum woni koli manga, jokke jungo, baabe haa cakka koli'en, be nder peɗɗeeli.

en: Artificial nails and chipped nail polish may harbor microorganisms.
ff: Peɗɗeeli je ɓe wati malla je ɗon heeffi foti mara gilɗiji.

en: Moisturizing lotion is often recommended to keep the hands from drying out; dry skin can lead to skin damage which can increase the risk for the transmission of infection.
ff: Neebam ɗigginugo ɓurna ɗon feelama ngam tato juɗe yora; yorugo laaral ɓanndu foti wona laaral ko foti ɓesda sallinol nyau.

en: Various low-cost options can be made to facilitate hand washing where tap-water and/or soap is not available e.g. pouring water from a hanging jerrycan or gourd with suitable holes and/or using ash if needed in developing countries.In situations with limited water supply (such as schools or rural areas in developing countries), there are water-conserving solutions, such as "tippy-taps" and other low-cost options.
ff: Dabareji feere je saɗɗay foti naffa ngam lallugo juɗe haa wakkere je ndiyam ɗon ila e/malla sabulu woda, bana ruffinugo ndiyam nder fayande malla buuta gal ngaskaji e/malla hoccugo ndoondi to woodi naffuda bana haa lesɗe je ɗon laffi masin. haa nder wakkati je ndiyam wala jur (bana haa jaangirdeji malla kawuyeji haa nder lesɗe je ɗon laffi masin), woodi dabare siggugo ndiyam, bana "tippy-taps" be dabareji feere je saɗɗay sam.

en: A tippy-tap is a simple technology using a jug suspended by a rope, and a foot-operated lever to pour a small amount of water over the hands and a bar of soap.
ff: Tippy tap laati dabare feere je ɗon wata fayande feere haa do ɓoogol be kuje feere je foti yaɓɓa diga les ngam ruffinugo seeɗa do juɗe be sabulu seeɗa.

en: Effective drying of the hands is an essential part of the hand hygiene process, but there is some debate over the most effective form of drying in public washrooms.
ff: Yorugo juɗe je kanduɗum laati yaɓɓorde boɗɗe haa laahal laɓɓinugo juɗe, amma woodi ngaba feere do dabare yorugo juɗe haa nder gaɗɗa suudu ummatore fu.

en: A growing volume of research suggests paper towels are much more hygienic than the electric hand dryers found in many washrooms.
ff: Teffolji ɗuɗɗum je ɗon wanga tum ɗo feela hoosugo takkarde gaɗɗa suudu do ordo yorugo juɗe haa nder gaɗɗa suudu ummatore.

en: In 2008, a study was conducted by the University of Westminster, London, and sponsored by the paper-towel industry the European Tissue Symposium, to compare the levels of hygiene offered by paper towels, warm-air hand dryers and the more modern jet-air hand dryers.
ff: haa 2008, ekkitol feere je ɓe ngaɗi haa haa University of Westminster, London, e be wallende suudu tagle takkarde gaɗɗa suudu European Tissue Symposium, ngam foondugo yaɓɓorde laɓɓinol je takkarde gaɗɗa suudu, ordo yorugo juɗe be ordooji je fuffata hendu ngam yorunugo juɗe.

en: After washing and drying hands with the warm-air dryer, the total number of bacteria was found to increase on average on the finger pads by 194% and on the palms by 254%.
ff: haa ɓaawo lallugo be yorugo juɗe be ordo yorugo juɗe, bacteriyaji fu je tawama ɗon ɓesda do leepolji koli'en be 194% e do juɗe 254%.

en: Drying with the jet-air dryer resulted in an increase on average of the total number of bacteria on the finger pads by 42% and on the palms by 15%.
ff: Yorugo be ordo je fuufatta hendu sappini ɓesdol bacteriyji fu haa do leepolji koli'en 42% be haa do juɗe 15%.

en: After washing and drying hands with a paper towel, the total number of bacteria was reduced on average on the finger pads by up to 76% and on the palms by up to 77%.The scientists also carried out tests to establish whether there was the potential for cross contamination of other washroom users and the washroom environment as a result of each type of drying method.
ff: haa ɓaawo yorugo juɗe be takkarde gaɗɗa suudu limgal bacteriyaji fu usti haa do leepolji koli'en be 76% be do juɗe haa 77%. Aandoɓe sallini lartolji ngam fammugo to foti raɓɓol salla diga huwooɓe gaɗɗa suddu feere be wakkereji gaɗɗa suudu bana haa sappinol kala dabare yorugo.

en: The jet-air dryer, which blows air out of the unit at claimed speeds of 180 m/s (650 km/h; 400 mph), was capable of blowing micro-organisms from the hands and the unit and potentially contaminating other washroom users and the washroom environment up to 2 metres away.
ff: Ordo yorugo gal foofugo hendu, je ɗon fuffa hendu be jaawal 180m/s (650 km/h; 400 mph), foti fuffa gilɗiji diga juɗe haa ordo e foti raɓɓa yimɓe je ɗon yuwa haa gaɗɗa suudu ndu be wakkere gaɗɗa suudu haa metaaji 2.

en: Use of a warm-air hand dryer spread micro-organisms up to 0.25 metres from the dryer.
ff: Huwidugo be ordo yorugo juɗe sankittol gilɗiji haa metaa 0.25 be ordo yorugo.

en: Paper towels showed no significant spread of micro-organisms.In 2005, in a study conducted by TÜV Produkt und Umwelt, different hand drying methods were evaluated.
ff: Takkarde gaɗɗa suudu sappinay sankittol gilɗiji sam. haa 2005, haa nder ekkitol feere je TÜV Pordukt und Umwelt, dabareji yarugo juɗe feere-feere sappinama.

en: The following changes in the bacterial count after drying the hands were observed:
ff: Nda ko ɗon tawama haa nder limtol bacteriyaji haa ɓaawo yornol juɗe:

en: Many different hand dryer manufacturers exist, and hand driers have been compared against drying with paper towels.
ff: Tagooɓe ordoji yorugo juɗe feere-feere ɗon, e ordoji yorugo juɗe do takkardeji gaɗɗa suudu.

en: Hand washing using hand sanitizing wipes is an alternative during traveling in the absence of soap and water.
ff: Lallugo juɗe be leepolji laɓɓinugo laati dabare feere haa wakkati jaahangal to wala sabulu be ndiyam.

en: Alcohol-based hand sanitizer should contain at least 60% alcohol.
ff: Kuje laɓɓinugo juɓe be alkol sey mara pettum man 60% alkol.

en: Medical hand-washing became mandatory long after Hungarian physician Ignaz Semmelweis discovered its effectiveness (in 1846) in preventing disease in a hospital environment.
ff: Lallugo juɗe laati dole haa ɓa lekkitowo Hungariya'en Ignaz Semmelweis tawi naffuda man (haa 1846) ngam aynol nyau haa nder wakkere suudu lekki feere.

en: There are electronic devices that provide feedback to remind hospital staff to wash their hands when they forget.
ff: Woodi ordoji je ɗon hokka sifturol haa huwooɓe suudu jam ɓanndu ngam lallugo juɗe maɓɓe to ɓe ho'itti.

en: One study has found decreased infection rates with their use.
ff: Ekkitol feere sappini ustol limtolji nyau to huwidi be man.

en: Medical hand-washing is for a minimum of 15 seconds, using generous amounts of soap and water or gel to lather and rub each part of the hands.
ff: Lallugo juɗe hoosan pettum man segonji 15, be sabulu seeɗa be ndiyam malla gel heɓɓa waɗa nguffu e yigga ndu boɗɗum.

en: Hands should be rubbed together with digits interlocking.
ff: Sey yigga jude boɗɗum be koli'en nder koli'en feere.

en: If there is debris under fingernails, a bristle brush may be used to remove it.
ff: To woodi cuddi haa nder peɗeeli, foti huwa be bros lottugo limse.

en: Since germs may remain in the water on the hands, it is important to rinse well and wipe dry with a clean towel.
ff: Ngam gilɗiji foti wonda haa do juɗe, laati kanduɗum lallugo be boɗɗe e yorina ɗum be limse laɓɗe.

en: After drying, the paper towel should be used to turn off the water (and open any exit door if necessary).
ff: haa ɓaawo yorugo, sey hoosa takkarde gaɗɗa suudu ngam darnugo ndiyam (e maɓɓitugo dammugal to woodi).

en: This avoids re-contaminating the hands from those surfaces.
ff: Ngam aynugo juɗe maa hoosa gilɗiji fahin.

en: The purpose of hand-washing in the health-care setting is to remove pathogenic microorganisms ("germs") and avoid transmitting them.
ff: Naffuda lallugo juɗe haa wakkereji jam ɓandu ndu laati ngam ittugo gilɗiji (gilɗi") e ayna sallinol majjum haa yimɓe feere.

en: The New England Journal of Medicine reports that a lack of hand-washing remains at unacceptable levels in most medical environments, with large numbers of doctors and nurses routinely forgetting to wash their hands before touching patients, thus transmitting microorganisms.
ff: The New England Journal of Medicine ɗon matina yo'o sallugo lallugo juɗe laati bana waɗatakke haa ɓurna wakkereji jam ɓanndu, be lekkitaɓe e ɓe'en je suklata do nyauɓe je ɗon ho'itta lallugo juɗe hiddeko memmugo nyauɓe, ndu sallina gilɗiji haa haa yimɓe feere.

en: One study showed that proper hand-washing and other simple procedures can decrease the rate of catheter-related bloodstream infections by 66 percent.The World Health Organization has published a sheet demonstrating standard hand-washing and hand-rubbing in health-care sectors.
ff: Ekkitol feere sappini yo'o lallugo juɗe be lawol man be laahalji feere foti ustina nyau je sallinata gal kateter haa nder iyam be 66%. Geeɓe Jam ɓanndu Duniyaru sappini batakkewol je ɗon hollina lallugo juɗe be yiggugo juɗe haa wakkereji jam ɓanndu.

en: The draft guidance of hand hygiene by the organization can also be found at its website for public comment.
ff: Batakkewol sappinol laɓɓinol juɗe je ɗowirɗe tawama haa do website maaɗa ngam ngewte ummatore.

en: A relevant review was conducted by Whitby et al.
ff: Lartol kanduɗum sallinama gal Whitby et al.

en: Commercial devices can measure and validate hand hygiene, if demonstration of regulatory compliance is required.
ff: Ordoji filu foti foonda e jaɓɓa laɓɓinol ɓanndu, to woodi emmol sappinol yahde umroji ndu.

en: The World Health Organization has "Five Moments" for washing hands:
ff: Geeɓe Jam ɓanndu Duniyaru woodi "wakkatiji Joowey" ngam lallugo juɗe:

en: after exposure to blood/body fluids
ff: haa ɓaawo memmugo iyam/ilam ɓanndu

en: before an aseptic task, and
ff: hiddeko kugal suklugo do nyauɗo, be

en: after patient care.The addition of antiseptic chemicals to soap ("medicated" or "antimicrobial" soaps) confers killing action to a hand-washing agent.
ff: haa ɓaawo suklugo do nyauɗo. Ɓesdugo kujeji mbarugo gilɗiji haa sabulu (sabuluji "suudu jam ɓanndu" malla "mbarugo gilɗiji") ɗon hokka sembe mbardugo haa kuje lallugo juɗe.

en: Such killing action may be desired prior to performing surgery or in settings in which antibiotic-resistant organisms are highly prevalent.To 'scrub' one's hands for a surgical operation, it is necessary to have a tap that can be turned on and off without touching it with the hands, some chlorhexidine or iodine wash, sterile towels for drying the hands after washing, and a sterile brush for scrubbing and another sterile instrument for cleaning under the fingernails.
ff: Irin kugal mbardugo foti naffa hiddeko seekugo nyauɗo malla haa wakkere je gilɗiji je ɗon mari semɓe nyaɗum ɗon wondi. Ngam 'yigugo' juɗe haa seekugo nyauɗo, laati kanduɗum marugo ndiyam je ɗon ila je goɗɗo foti maɓɓita malla maɓɓa bila memmugo be juɗe, lallugo be chlorhexidine malla iodine, leepolji je meeɗay huwugo be man, be bross je yiggugo be kujeji laɓɗe ngam laɓɓinugo peɗeeli.

en: All jewelry should be removed.
ff: Sey itta halagaare fu.

en: This procedure requires washing the hands and forearms up to the elbow, usually 2–6 minutes.
ff: Laahal ndu ɗon emma lallugo juɗe diga les haa do, ɓurna fu nder minti 2-6.

en: Long scrub-times (10 minutes) are not necessary.
ff: Neɓɓugo jur do yiggugo (minti 10) wala naffuda.

en: When rinsing, water on the forearms must be prevented from running back to the hands.
ff: haa yakke lallitugo, tato ndiyam je ɗon haa do toɓɓa haa nder juɗe fahin.

en: After hand-washing is completed, the hands are dried with a sterile cloth and a surgical gown is donned.
ff: haa ɓaawo timminol lallugo juɗe, sey yora juɗe be limse laɓɗe e ɓorna ngapaleewol seekowo do man.

en: To reduce the spread of germs, it is better to wash the hands or use a hand antiseptic before and after tending to a sick person.
ff: Ngam ustugo sankittol gilɗiji, kanduɗum lallugo juɗe malla kujeji laɓɓinugo juɗe hiddeko e haa ɓaawo suklugo do nyauɓe.

en: For control of staphylococcal infections in hospitals, it has been found that the greatest benefit from hand-cleansing came from the first 20% of washing, and that very little additional benefit was gained when hand cleansing frequency was increased beyond 35%.
ff: Ngam aynol nyauji staphilocok haa nder cuuɗi jam ɓanndu, ɗon holli yo'o riba maungel nder laɓɓinugo juɗe wari haa 20% arandere lallol, e ɓesdare pamaron ndu wangi haa yakke limtol laɓɓinol juɗe ɓesdi haa gaɗɗa 35%.

en: Washing with plain soap results in more than triple the rate of bacterial infectious disease transmitted to food as compared to washing with antibacterial soap.Comparing hand-rubbing with alcohol-based solution with hand washing with antibacterial soap for a median time of 30 seconds each showed that the alcohol hand-rubbing reduced bacterial contamination 26% more than the antibacterial soap.
ff: Lallugo be sabulu meere ɗon sappina nde tati limtol nyau bacteriyaji je ɗon raɓɓa je sallini haa nyamdu do foodol be lallugo be sabulu je mbardugo bacteriyaji. Foondugo yiggugo juɗe be kuje je ɗon mari alkol be lallugo juɗe be sabulu je mbardugo bacteriyaji haa nder segonji 30 feere-feere sappini yo'o lallugo juɗe je kuje je ɗon mari alkol ustini raɓɓol bacteriyaji be 26% ɓuri je lallotto be sabulu mbardugo bacteriyaji.

en: But soap and water is more effective than alcohol-based hand rubs for reducing H1N1 influenza A virus and Clostridium difficile spores from hands.Interventions to improve hand hygiene in healthcare settings can involve education for staff on hand washing, increasing the availability of alcohol-based hand rub, and written and verbal reminders to staff.
ff: Amma sabulu be ndiyam ɓuri naffugo do kujeji laɓɓinugo je ɗon mari alkol ngam ustinugo viriis ndamba H1N1 A be Clostridium difficile spores nder juɗe. Dabareji ɓesdugo hakiika lallugo juɗe haa nder wakkereji jam ɓanndu foti larna aandal huwooɓe do lottugo juɗe, je ɗon ɓesda wondugo kuje lallugo juɗe je ɗon mari alkol, be siftirol je ɗon windi e je ɗon be hunduko haa huwooɓe.

en: There is a need for more research into which of these interventions are most effective in different healthcare settings.
ff: woodi haaje teffol feere je dabareji ndu laati kanduɗum haa nder wakkereji jam ɓanndu feere.

en: In developing countries, hand washing with soap is recognized as a cost-effective, essential tool for achieving good health, and even good nutrition.
ff: haa nder lesɗe je ɗon laffi masitin, lallugo juɗe be sabulu ɗon andi bana ɗon buuti, dabare kanduɗum ngam jam ɓanndu, be nyamɗe boɗɗe.

en: However, a lack of reliable water supply, soap or hand washing facilities in people's homes, at schools and at the workplace make it a challenge to achieve universal hand washing behaviors.
ff: Be man fu, to walla ndiyam je ila boɗɗum, sabulu malla wakkereji lallugo juɗ haa saare yimɓe, haa jaangirde be haa baabe kugal latina ɗum bana saɗirma nder gikku lallugo juɗe je boɗɗum.

en: For example, in most of rural Africa hand washing taps close to every private or public toilet are scarce, even though cheap options exist to build hand washing stations.
ff: Bana sappinol, haa ɓurna kawyeji Afirika, caɗɗum heɓɓugo baabe lallugo juɗe je ndiyam ndiyam ɗon ila boɗɗum haa nder gaɗɗa suddu goɗɗo malla je ummatore, ko to woodi dabareji mahugo wakkereji lallugo juɗe je kooyɗum.

en: However, low hand washing rates rather can also be the result of engrained habits rather than due to a lack of soap or water.
ff: Amma, foti limtol lallugo ɓanndu ɗon lessi bo'o ngam nastay nder gikku maɓɓe do ngam wala sabulu malla ndiyam.

en: The promotion and advocacy of hand washing with soap can influence policy decisions, raise awareness about the benefits of hand washing and lead to long-term behavior change of the population.
ff: Feelore be sembintinol ngam lallugo juɗe be sabulu foti memma siyasa hasduji, hollina ribaji lallugo juɗe e saanjan gikku ummatore haa yeeso.

en: For this to work effectively, monitoring and evaluation are necessary.
ff: Ngam heɓɓa dabare ndu huwa be gonga, aynol be lartol laati kanduɗum.

en: A systematic review of 70 studies found that community-based approaches are effective at increasing hand washing in LMICs, while social marketing campaigns are less effective.One example for hand washing promotion in schools is the "Three Star Approach" by UNICEF that encourages schools to take simple, inexpensive steps to ensure that students wash their hands with soap, among other hygienic requirements.
ff: Lartol ekkitolji 70 sappini yo'o dabareji gal badittugo ummatore laati kanduɗum ngam ɓesdugo lallugo juɗe haa LMIC, haa wakkati feere bo'o feeloji haa ummatore ngam sippugo hokkata ɓiɓe. woodi sappinol feere ngam feelore ngam lallugo juɗe haa jaangirdeji laati dabare je mbiyotto "Dabare Kode Tati" gal UNICEF je ɗon sembintina jaangirdeji ngam hoosa yaɓɓordeji kooyɗum ngam aandinugo yo'o jaangoɓe ɗon lalla juɗe maɓɓe be sabulu, haa cakka dabareji laɓɓinol feere.

en: When minimum standards are achieved, schools can move from one to ultimately three stars.
ff: To tawretaji arandere laati bana heɗɗitotto, jaangirdeji foti umma diga kode gooto haa tati.

en: Building hand washing stations can be a part of hand washing promotion campaigns that are carried out in order to reduce diseases and child mortality.
ff: Mahugo baabe lallugo juɗe foti nasta nder dabareji feelore ngam lallugo juɗe je hasdotto ngam ustugo nyauji be limtol mayde ɓikkon.

en: Global Hand washing Day is another example of an awareness-raising campaign that is trying to achieve behavior change.As a result of the 2019-20 coronavirus pandemic, UNICEF promoted the adoption of a handwashing emoji.
ff: Balɗe Duniyaru ngam Lallugo juɗe laati bana sappinol feere je dassata hakkilo ummatore je yardi yimɓe saanja gikku. Ngam nyau koronaviriis 2019-20, UNICEF feeli jaɓɓugo didol lallugo juɗe.

en: Few studies have considered the overall cost effectiveness of hand washing in developing countries in relationship to DALYs averted.
ff: Ekkitolji seeɗa waɗi lisafi ceede je ko lallugo juɗe foti hoosa haa nder lesɗe je ɗon laffi be ko DALY matini.

en: However, one review suggests that promoting hand washing with soap is significantly more cost-effective than other water and sanitation interventions.
ff: Amma, woodi lartol feere je ɗon sappina yo'o feelugo lallugo juɗe be sabulu ɓuri buutugo do dabareji addugo ndiyam malla jam ɓanndu feere.

en: The importance of hand washing for human health – particularly for people in vulnerable circumstances like mothers who had just given birth or wounded soldiers in hospitals – was first recognized in the mid 19th century by two pioneers of hand hygiene: the Hungarian physician Ignaz Semmelweis who worked in Vienna, Austria and Florence Nightingale, the English "founder of modern nursing".
ff: Naffuda lallugo juɗe haa nder yonki neɗɗo, ɓurna ummatore je ɗon woni haa nder saɗirmaji feere bana daadiraɓe je ɓeesni malla soje'en je ɗon nawni je wondi haa nder cuuɗi lekki, wangi haa cakare hittande 1900 gal haɓdooɓe ngam laɓɓinol ɓanndu: Lekkitawo Hungariya'en Ignaz Semmelweis je huwidi haa Vienna, Ostriya be Florence Nightingale, "daada sukloowo jam ɓanndu" Inglisiya.

en: At that time most people still believed that infections were caused by foul odors called miasmas.
ff: haa wakkati nde ɓurna yimɓe tammi no yo'o ko hokkata nyauji woni haccengaji je woɗay je ewnotto miasma.

en: In the 1980s, foodborne outbreaks and healthcare-associated infections led the United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to more actively promote hand hygiene as an important way to prevent the spread of infection.
ff: Gal 1980, nyauji je salli gal nyamɗe be nyauji je laarani jam ɓanndu waɗi Ɗowirɗe Aynol e Lartol Nyau haa Lesɗe America ngam feelugo laɓɓinol juɗe bana dabare kanduɗum nder aynol sankittol nyau.

en: The outbreak of swine flu in 2009 and the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020 led to increased awareness in many countries of the importance of washing hands with soap to protect oneself from such infectious diseases.
ff: Wangol nyau ndamba gaduru haa 2009 be nyau COVID-19 haa 2020 ɓesdini dassugo hakiika haa nder lesɗe ɗuɗɗum ngam naffuda lallugo juɗe be sabulu ngam fadugo hoore mum ngam irin nyauji ndu.

en: For example, posters with "correct hand washing techniques" were hung up next to hand washing sinks in public toilets and in the toilets of office buildings and airports in Germany.
ff: Bana sappinol, fotoji be "sappinolji lallugo juɗe je kanduɗum" ɗon no ɓilli haa baabe lalluggo juɗe haa nder gaɗɗa suudu ummatore be gaɗɗa suudu cuuɗi kugal be wakkere jippol pireewolji haa Jaamani.

en: The phrase "washing one's hands of" something, means declaring one's unwillingness to take responsibility for the thing or share complicity in it.
ff: Wolde "lallugo juɗe mum ngam" kuje feere, yiɗi wi'ugo yo'o hollinugo a yarday nastinugo hoore maaɗa haa nder kuje malla lata bana walloowo.

en: It originates from the bible passage in Matthew where Pontius Pilate washed his hands of the decision to crucify Jesus Christ, but has become a phrase with a much wider usage in some English communities.
ff: Fuɗɗi haa nder deftere nder Matta je Pontius Pilaatus lalli juɗe mako nder hasduye waffugo Yeesu Kristi, amma laati boleeɗe je yiɗi wi'ugo kujeji jur haa nder ummatore Inglisiya.

en: In Shakespeare's Macbeth, Lady Macbeth begins to compulsively wash her hands in an attempt to cleanse an imagined stain, representing her guilty conscience regarding crimes she had committed and induced her husband to commit.
ff: haa Macbeth Shakespeare, Lady Macbeth fuɗɗi be lallugo juɗe mako ngam o yiɗi no wilugo aybe feere je ɗon nder hakkilo mako, je ɗon sappina hakke mako do mbarol je o waɗi gorko mako nasti nder majuum.

en: It has also been found that people, after having recalled or contemplated unethical acts, tend to wash hands more often than others, and tend to value hand washing equipment more.
ff: Tawama bo'o ummatore, haa ɓaawo sirturol malla nummol kuje je yahay, ɗon lalla juɗ maɓɓe haa wakkati fu ɓuri yimɓe feere do yimɓe feere, e yardi hokkugo mangu haa kujeji lallugo juɗe.

en: Furthermore, those who are allowed to wash their hands after such a contemplation are less likely to engage in other "cleansing" compensatory actions, such as volunteering.
ff: Fahin bo'o, yimɓe je ɗon mari jarfuye lallugo juɗe haa ɓaawo irin kujeji ndu yarday hasdugo kuɗe "laɓɓinol" bana wallende.

en: Religions prescribe hand washing for both hygienic and symbolic purposes.Symbolic hand washing, using water but no soap to wash hands, is a part of ritual hand washing featured in many religions, including Bahá'í Faith, Hinduism, tevilah and netilat yadayim in Judaism, Lavabo in Christianity, and Wudhu in Islam.Religions also prescribe hygienic hand washing, especially after certain actions.
ff: Dina'en ɗon feela lallugo juɗe ngam dabare laɓɓinol be sappinol. Sappinol lallugo juɗe, be ndiyam bila sabulu, laati bana ɗon nasta nder deewal dina'en feere jur, bana Dina Bahá'í, Hinduism, tevilah be netilat yadayim nder Judaism, Lavabo nder Maasinkoo'en, be Wudhu nder Islam. Dina'en bo'o ɗon feela lallugo juɗe, ɓurna fu haa ɓaawo kujeji.

en: Hinduism, Judaism and Islam mandate washing of hands after using the toilet.
ff: Hinduism, Judaism be Islam ɗon feere lallugo juɗe haa wurtol gaɗɗa suudu.

en: And, Hinduism, Buddhism, Sikhism, Judaism and Islam mandate washing of hands before and after every meal.
ff: E, Hinduism, Buddhism, Sikhism, Judaism be Islam ɗon feela lallugo juɗe hiddeko e haa ɓaawo kala nyamdu fu.

en: Impact of the 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic on education
ff: Saklere nyau koronaviriis 2019-20 do jaangirde

en: The 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic has affected educational systems worldwide, leading to the widespread closures of schools and universities.
ff: Nyau koronaviriis 2019-20 memmi jaahargal jaangirdeji haa nder duniyaru fu, je waɗi jaangirdeji be jam'iareji ɓurna fu nder duniyaru maɓɓi.

en: As of 8 April 2020, approximately 1.716 billion learners have been affected due to school closures in response to COVID-19.
ff: haa 8 Aviiril 2020, deydey jaangoɓe miliarji 1.716 memmotto ngam maɓɓolji jaangirde ngam jabbuye haa COVID-19.

en: According to UNESCO monitoring, 188 countries have implemented nationwide closures and 5 have implemented local closures, impacting about 99.4% of the world's student population.
ff: haa larto UNESCO, lesɗe 188 maɓɓi dammuɗe maɓɓe do lesdi man fu be 5 maɓɓi haa wakkereji feere tan, ko memmi ɓadi 99.4% ummatore jaangoɓe duniyaru fu.

en: On 23 March 2020, Cambridge International Examinations (CIE) released a statement announcing the cancellation of Cambridge IGCSE, Cambridge O Level, Cambridge International AS & A Level, Cambridge AICE Diploma, and Cambridge Pre-U examinations for the May/June 2020 series across all countries.
ff: haa 23 Maars 2020, Cambridge International Examinations (CIE) wurtini matinol je ɗon no darna IGCSE Cambridge, Cambridge O Level, Cambridge International AS & A Level, Cambridge AICE Diploma, be bindolji Cambridge Pre-U je Me/Zwiing 2020 haa nder lesɗe fu.

en: International Baccalaureate exams have also been cancelled.School closures impact not only students, teachers, and families, but have far-reaching economic and societal consequences.
ff: Bindi International Baccalaureate woni darnotto bo'o. Maɓɓolji jaangirde memmay tan jaangoɓe, jaanginooɓe, be calaaje, amma memmi bo'o jonde nder ummatore be siggordeji.

en: School closures in response to COVID-19 have shed light on various social and economic issues, including student debt, digital learning, food insecurity, and homelessness, as well as access to childcare, health care, housing, internet, and disability services.
ff: Maɓɓolji jaangirde ngam jabbuye haa COVID-19 ngewti do saɗirmaji ummatore be siggorde, be nyaamande jaangoɓe, ekkitol gal ordo, larula be nyamɗe, be wondugo bila saare, be nastirde haa suklare do ɓikkon, saare, internaati be kuɗe do yimɓe je mari nyau diga danyinki.

en: The impact was more severe for disadvantaged children and their families, causing interrupted learning, compromised nutrition, childcare problems, and consequent economic cost to families who could not work.In response to school closures, UNESCO recommended the use of distance learning programmes and open educational applications and platforms that schools and teachers can use to reach learners remotely and limit the disruption of education.
ff: Ndu laati ɓuri sembe ɓikkon be caalage je maray dabareji feere, je ngaɗi ɓe darni jaangirde, maray nyamdu boɗɗe, mari larulaaji ngam wala goɗɗo je suklata do ɓikkon, be asaarji je calaaje je footay huwa ɗon matta. Jabbugo haa maɓɓolji jaangirde UNESCO ɗon feela jaahargal ekkitolji daayindi e emmolji jaangirde be daaldalji je jaangirdeji be jaangoɓe foti jokka jaangoɓe gal dabareji daayindi e darni jaangirde.

en: Efforts to stem the spread of COVID-19 through non-pharmaceutical interventions and preventive measures such as social-distancing and self-isolation have prompted the widespread closure of primary, secondary, and tertiary schooling in over 100 countries.Previous outbreaks of infectious diseases have prompted widespread school closings around the world, with varying levels of effectiveness.
ff: Dabareji darnugo sankittol COVID-19 gal dabareji je wonday gal lekki malla aynol bana dayol ummatore be wondugo haa sera be hoore mum yaawini maɓɓol jaangirdeji aranool, ɗiɗiɗaɓool, be tataɓool haa nder lesɗe 100. Nyauji warango yaawini maɓɓolji jaangirde haa der nder duniyaru, be yajjol ndu ɗon saanja be wakkere e lesdi.

en: Mathematical modelling has shown that transmission of an outbreak may be delayed by closing schools.
ff: Sappinol limtol sappini yo' o sallinol nyau foti ɗaaya gal maɓɓugo cuuɗi jaangirdeji.

en: However, effectiveness depends on the contacts children maintain outside of school.
ff: Amma, goongakku man wondi do foti ngaɗa haa ɓaawo suudu jaangirde.

en: School closures may be effective when enacted promptly.
ff: Maɓɓolji jaangirde foti naffa to waɗatto be wakkati.

en: If school closures occur late relative to an outbreak, they are less effective and may not have any impact at all.
ff: To maɓɓolji jaangirde yotti be ɗaayol, marata naffuda jur e foti marata sembe sam maa.

en: Additionally, in some cases, the reopening of schools after a period of closure has resulted in increased infection rates.
ff: Fahin bo'o, haa wakkere feere, maɓɓitol jaangirdeji haa ɓaawo wakkati maɓɓol waɗi limtolji nyauɓe ɓesdi.

en: As closures tend to occur concurrently with other interventions such as public gathering bans, it can be difficult to measure the specific impact of school closures.During the 1918-1919 influenza pandemic in the United States, school closures and public gathering bans were associated with lower total mortality rates.
ff: Bana maɓɓolji ɗon yahida be dabareji feere bana haɗɗol mofturde ummatore, foti lato caɗɗum foondugo ko maɓɓolji jaangirde ndu wadi. haa wakkati nyau ndamba haa 1918-1919 haa nder Lesɗe America, maɓɓolji jaangirde be haɗɗol mofturde ummatore yahidi no be limtol mayɓe je wonay jur.

en: Cities that implemented such interventions earlier had greater delays in reaching peak mortality rates.
ff: Berniji je huwidi be dabareji ndu diga fuɗɗam man daayi no ngam jokkittugo limtolji mayde ndu.

en: Schools closed for a median duration of 4 weeks according to a study of 43 US cities' response to the Spanish Flu.
ff: Jaangirdeji maɓɓakke haa nder deydey asaweji 4 bana sappinol ekkitol jabbuji berni Lesɗe America 43.

en: School closures were shown to reduce morbidity from the Asian flu by 90% during the 1957–58 outbreak, and up to 50% in controlling influenza in the US, 2004–2008.Multiple countries successfully slowed the spread of infection through school closures during the 2009 H1N1 Flu pandemic.
ff: Maɓɓolji jaangirde woni no bana ustan limtol mayde nyauɓe Ndamba Asia je 1957-58, e haa 50% ngam lartugo nyau haa Lesɗe America, 2004-2008. Lesɗe ɗuɗɗum ɗaayini yahde sankittol nyau gal maɓɓolji jaangirde haa yakke nyau H1N1 2009.

en: School closures in the city of Oita, Japan, were found to have successfully decreased the number of infected students at the peak of infection; however closing schools was not found to have significantly decreased the total number of infected students.
ff: Maɓɓolji jaangirde haa nder berniwol Oita, Japan, tawama bana ustini limtol jaangoɓe je nyauɗo; amma maɓɓolji jaangirde latay dabare ustugo limtol jaangoɓe fu je mari nyau ndu be gonga.

en: Mandatory school closures and other social distancing measures were associated with a 29% to 37% reduction in influenza transmission rates.
ff: Maɓɓolji jaangirde be dabareji daayol ummatore yahidi no be jippol 29% haa 37% be limtol sallinol ndamba.

en: Early school closures in the United States delayed the peak of the 2009 H1N1 Flu pandemic.
ff: Maɓɓolji jaangirde be wakkati haa nder Lesɗe America ɗaayini nyau ndamba H1N1 je 2009.

en: Despite the overall success of closing schools, a study of school closures in Michigan found that "district level reactive school closures were ineffective."During the swine flu outbreak in 2009 in the UK, in an article titled "Closure of schools during an influenza pandemic" published in the Lancet Infectious Diseases, a group of epidemiologists endorsed the closure of schools in order to interrupt the course of the infection, slow further spread and buy time to research and produce a vaccine.
ff: Ko to cuuɗi jaangirde fu maɓɓi, ekkitol do maɓɓolji jaangirde haa Michigan sappini yo'o "maɓɓolji jaangirde haa nder distrik maray naffuda." haa wakkati nyau ndamba gaduru haa 2009 haa Lesɗe Inglisiya, woodi batakkewol feere je hoore man "Closure of schools during an influenza pandemic" je wurti haa nder Lancet Infectious Diseases, geeɓe aandooɓe nyau je ɗon raɓɓa hasdi maɓɓolji jaangirde ngam darnugo yahde nyau ndu, ɗaayina, e heɓɓa wakkati ngam wurtinugo baatal.

en: Having studied previous influenza pandemics including the 1918 flu pandemic, the influenza pandemic of 1957 and the 1968 flu pandemic, they reported on the economic and workforce effect school closure would have, particularly with a large percentage of doctors and nurses being women, of whom half had children under the age of 16.
ff: Ngam ɓe jaangi nyauji ndamba je sallingobe nyauji ndambe 1918, nyau ndamba 1957 be nyau ndamba 1968, ɓe matini do ko maɓɓolji jaangirde foti mara bana saɗirma do siggorde ceede malla jonde ummatore, ɓurna bo'o be limtol lekkitoɓe be sukloɓe do jam ɓanndu je woni rewɓe, je reeta maɓɓe ɗon mari ɓikkon je maray duuɓi 16.

en: They also looked at the dynamics of the spread of influenza in France during French school holidays and noted that cases of flu dropped when schools closed and re-emerged when they re-opened.
ff: Fahin bo'o, ɓe lari yahde sankittol ndamba haa Faraansa haa wakkati siwtare jaangirdeji maɓɓe e fammi yo'o nyauɓe ndamba usti haa yakke jaangirdeji maɓɓi e ɓesdi haa yakke je jaangirdeji maɓɓitti.

en: They noted that when teachers in Israel went on strike during the flu season of 1999–2000, visits to doctors and the number of respiratory infections dropped by more than a fifth and more than two fifths respectively.
ff: Ɓe fammi yo'o haa yakke je jaanginoɓe turti haa akati ndamba haa 1999-2000, ngilli haa lekkitoɓe be limgal nyauji pofɗe usti be ɓuri reeta be ɗiɗi nder joowey.

en: For schools and childcare facilities, the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends short-term closure to clean or disinfect if an infected person has been in a school building regardless of community spread.
ff: Ko laarani jaangirdeji be wakkereji suklugo do ɓikkon, Ɗowirɗe Aynol e Lartol Jam ɓanndu Lesɗe America feeli maɓɓol haa nder wakkati seeɗa tan ngam laɓɓugo malla laɓɓinugo to woodi nyaudo no haa nder wakkere jaangirde bila larugo sankittol nyau haa cakka ummatore.

en: When there is minimal to moderate community transmission, social distancing strategies can be implemented such as cancelling field trips, assemblies, and other large gatherings such as physical education or choir classes or meals in a cafeteria, increasing the space between desks, staggering arrival and dismissal times, limiting nonessential visitors, and using a separate health office location for children with flu-like symptoms.
ff: To woodi dabare sallinol seeɗa haa deydey, dabareji dayol be ummatore foti naffa bana darnugo wurtol jaangirde haa ngilli, moftude, be kawtirdeji maungel bana ekkitolji espor, gimmol malla nyammugo haa suudu nyaɗe, ɓesdugo baabe haa kunde koroomje lartugo wakkati yottugo be je hottugo, darnugo ngilli meere-meere, be neldugo jaangoɓe je bana mari ndamba haa suudu lekki feere.

en: When there is substantial transmission in the local community, in addition to social distancing strategies, extended school dismissals may be considered.
ff: To woodi sallinol kanduɗum haa cakka ummatore, ɓesdugo do dabareji dayol ummatore, darnolji jaangirde haa nder wakkati juttungel sey lartotto.

en: On 26 January, China instituted measures to contain the COVID-19 outbreak which included extending the Spring Festival holiday to contain the outbreak.
ff: haa 26 Zaanviye, Cayna wurtini dabareji ngam darnugo nyau COVID-19 je laarani yarɓugo julde Spring Festival haa ɓaawo ngam darnugo nyau ndu.

en: Universities and schools around the country closed.
ff: Jam'iareji be jaangirdeji haa nder tarde ndu maɓɓakke.

en: On 23 February, Iran's Ministry of Health announced the closure of universities, higher educational institutions and schools in several cities and provinces.
ff: haa 23 Feviriye, Arduɗo Jam ɓanndu Iran matini maɓɓol jam'iareji, jaangirdeji maungel be jaangirdeji haa nder lamordeji ɗuɗɗum.

en: On 3 March, UNESCO released the first global numbers on school closures and affected students.
ff: haa 3 Maars, UNESCO wurtini arandere limgal jaangirdeji je ɗon maɓɓi be ɓikkon je ɗon memmi.

en: It reported that 13 countries had enacted preventive measures including the temporary closure of schools and universities, impacting 290.5 million students around the world.
ff: Matinama yo'o lesɗe 13 hoosi dabareji aynol bana maɓɓolji jaangirde be jam'iareji nder wakkati seeɗa, ko memmi jaangoɓe milionji 290.5 haa nder duniyaru.

en: In reaction, UNESCO called on countries to support affected students and families and facilitate large-scale inclusive distance learning programmes.
ff: Bana jabbuye, UNESCO ewni lesɗe ngam wallugo jaangoɓe be calaaje je ɗon memmi e hasda ngam jaahargalji ekkitol daayinde.

en: On 4 March, the Italian government ordered the full closure of all schools and universities nationwide as Italy reached 100 deaths.
ff: haa 4 Maars, ngomna Italy hasdi maɓɓolji jaangirdeji be jam'iareji fu haa do lesdi Italy bana yimɓe 100 maynama ngam nyau ndu.

en: In doing so, Italy became one of 22 countries on three continents which had announced or implemented school closures.
ff: Gal dabare ndu, Italy laati lesɗe 22 haa do hawtirde lesdi tati je matini malla hasdi ngam maɓɓugo jaangirdeji.

en: On 5 March, the majority of learners affected by COVID-19 emergency measures were located in China, with 233 million learners affected, followed by Japan at 16.5 million and Iran at 14.5 million.
ff: haa 5 Maars, ɓurna jaangoɓe je dabareji jaawal COVID-19 memmi ɓe wondi no haa Cayna, jaangoɓe milionji 233 memmotto, tokkiti be Japan be milionji 16.5 e Iran be milionji 14.5.

en: By 10 March, one in five students worldwide was "staying away from school due to the COVID-19 crisis" while another one in four was barred from higher education institutions.
ff: haa 10 Maars, gooto nder jaangoɓe joowey woni "dayiɗum be jaangirde ngam nyau COVID-19" haa wakkati feere gooto nder jaangoɓe nay fartakke haa jaangirdeji je maungel.

en: On 13 March, governments in 49 countries announced or implemented school closures, including 39 countries which closed schools nationwide and 22 countries with localised school closures.
ff: haa 13 Maars, ngomna'en haa nder lesɗe 49 matini malla hasdi maɓɓolji jaangirde, be lesɗe 39 je maɓɓi jaangirde haa do lesdi maɓɓe fu e lesɗe 22 darni jaangirde haa wakkere feere tan.

en: By 16 March, this figure increased from 49 to 73 countries according to UNESCO.
ff: haa 16 Maars, limgal ngel ummi diga lesɗe 49 haa 73 haa matinol UNESCO.

en: By 19 March, 50% of students worldwide were affected by school closures, corresponding to nationwide closures in 102 countries and local closures in 11 countries affecting 850 million children and youth.
ff: haa 19 Maars, 50% jaangoɓe memmotto ngam maɓɓolji jaangirde, je waɗi limgal man haa nder duniyaru fu haa lesɗe 102 be darnolji 11 haa wakkereji feere, ko memmi ɓikkon be sukaɓe milionji 850.

en: By 20 March, over 70% of the world's learners were impacted by closures, with 124 country-wide school closures.
ff: haa 20 Maars, ɓuri 70% jaangoɓe haa nder duniyaru memmotto be maɓɓolji, be maɓɓolji 124 haa nder lesɗe fu.

en: On 23 March, all Nigerian school were found to have been closed down by Nigerian government, markets as well as companies were closed down and children were forbidden by parents to step out of their homes.
ff: haa 23 Maars, ngomna Nigeriya maɓɓi jaangirdeji fu haa do lesdi maaɗa, lumoji be cuuɗi maungel bo'o maɓɓakke e baabiraɓe haɗɗi ɓikkon maɓɓe wurtugo haa yaasi.

en: On 26 March, all New Zealand schools and universities have been closed down across the country.
ff: haa 26 Maars, jaangirdeji be jam'ireji New Zealand fu maɓɓakke haa do lesdi man fu.

en: The government has imposed a two-week holiday, allowing schools to transition to forms of distant teaching as soon as possible.
ff: Ngomna hasdi asawereji ɗiɗi ngam wondugo haa saare, ngam heɓɓa jaangirdeji salla haa dabareji jaangirde dayindi bana ko wowa.

en: Universities have closed for one week, but resumed with online teaching afterwards.
ff: Jam'iareji maɓɓakke nder asawere gooto, amma fuɗɗiti be jaangirde do internati haa ɓaawo man.

en: Other school services remain open, but teaching is restricted to distant learning.
ff: Kuɗe jaangirdeji laati maɓɓitama, amma jaangirde jooɗi do je dayindi go.

en: By 27 March, nearly 90 percent of the world's student population was out of class.
ff: haa 27 Maars, ɓadi 90% hawtirde ummatore jaangoɓe haa duniyaru wurtakke suudu jaangirde.

en: Regions with schools remaining open included Taiwan, Singapore, Australia, Sweden, and some U.S. states.
ff: Wakkereji be jaangirdeji je wonotto maɓɓitama haa Taiwan, Singapore, Australia, Sweden e feere'en haa Lesɗe America.

en: By 29 March, more than 1.5 billion children and other students were affected by nationwide school closures.
ff: haa 29 Maars, ɓuri ɓikkon miliarji 1.5 be jaangoɓe feere memmotto ngam maɓɓolji jaangirdeji haa do lesdi fu.

en: Others were disrupted by localized closures.
ff: Feere'en darnotto ngam maɓɓolji nder wakkere nde.

en: Until April 6, holidays were extended in all secondary schools of Turkmenistan.
ff: haa 6 Aviiril, siwtare ɓesdotto haa nder jaangirdeji diɗaɓool fu haa Turkmenistan.

en: An order signed by the Ministry of Education as a preventative measure aims to prevent the spread of respiratory diseases in connection with the WHO coronavirus pandemic.
ff: Umrore feere je Arduɗo Jaangirde waɗi jungo do man bana dabare aynol yiɗi darnugo sankittol nyauji pofɗe be nyau koronaviriis WHO.

en: 10 countries have localised schools closures, UNESCO estimates 473,933,356 learners are potentially at risk (pre-primary to upper-secondary education) and 77,938,904 learners are potentially at risk in tertiary education.
ff: Lesɗe 10 maɓɓi suudu jaangirde haa wakkereji feere, UNESCO matini yo'o foti jaangoɓe 473 933 356 maran larulaaji (diga jaarne haa jaangirde ɗiɗaɓre) be jaangooɓe 77 938 904 foti mara larulaaji haa jaangirde tataɓool.

en: Note: Figures correspond to total number of learners enrolled at pre-primary, primary, lower-secondary, and upper-secondary levels of education [ISCED levels 0 to 3], as well as at tertiary education levels [ISCED levels 5 to 8] who could be affected should localised closures become countrywide.
ff: Mandol: Limgal laarani hawtirde jaangoɓe je windama haa jaarne, aranool, ɗiɗaɓool les, be ɗiɗaɓool do [ISCED yaɓɓorde 0 haa 3], bana haa yaɓɓorde jaangirde tataɓool [ISCED yaɓɓorde 5 haa 8] je foti memmotto to maɓɓolji hoosi lesdi fu.

en: Enrolment figures based on latest UNESCO Institute of Statistics data.
ff: Limgal nastukki do ragare matinolji Institute of Statistics UNESCO.

en: School closures in response to the COVID-19 pandemic have shed a light on numerous issues affecting access to education, as well as broader socio-economic issues.
ff: Maɓɓolji jaangideji ngam jabbuye haa COVID-19 ngewti do kujeji jur je saklatta nastirde haa dabare jaangirde, be larulaaji ummatore be je siggorde ceede.

en: As of March 12, more than 370 million children and youth are not attending school because of temporary or indefinite country wide school closures mandated by governments in an attempt to slow the spread of COVID-19.
ff: haa 12 Maars, ɓuri ɓikkon be sukkaɓe milionji 370 wala yahugo haa suudu jaangirde ngam ngomna'en wangini umrore do darnol jaangirdeji haa nder lesdi haa nder wakkati seeɗa malla deydey ngam ɗaayinugo sankittol COVID-19.

en: As of 29 March, nearly 90% of the world's learners were impacted by closures.Even when school closures are temporary, it carries high social and economic costs.
ff: haa 29 Maars, ɓadi 90% jaangoɓe duniyaru memmotto ngam maɓɓol. Ko to ɓe darni jaangirdeji ndu nder wakkati seeɗa tan, ɗon ngada majjinol ceede jur haa nder ummatore be siggorde.

en: The disruptions they cause affect people across communities, but their impact is more severe for disadvantaged children and their families including interrupted learning, compromised nutrition, childcare problems and consequent economic cost to families who cannot work.
ff: Darnolji je ɓe wadi ɗon memma yimɓe haa nder ummatore, amma kuɗe man latan caɗɗum haa ɓikkon be calaaje je maray dabare feere bana ekkitol, nyamɗe je kalluɗum, saɗirmaji ɓikkon be majjol ceede je ɗon tokki haa calaaje je footay huwa sam.

en: Working parents are more likely to miss work when schools close in order to take care of their children, incurring wage loss in many instances and negatively impacting productivity.
ff: Baabiraɓe je ɗon huwa ɓurna yahatta kugal to jaangirdeji maɓɓi ngam suklugo do ɓikkon maɓɓe, ko ɗon waɗa ceede lewru maɓɓe ustan haa nder wakkere jur e ko ɗon memma marde maɓɓe.

en: Localised school closures place burdens on schools as parents and officials redirect children to schools that are open.
ff: Maɓɓolji jaangirde haa wakkereji feere tan ndu ɗon hokka doongal haa baabiraɓe be arduɓe neldan ɓikkon haa jaangirdeji je ɗon maɓɓiti.

en: Women often represent a large share of health-care workers and often cannot attend work because of childcare obligations that result from school closures.
ff: Rewɓe ɓurna fu on suklatta do nyauɓe haa cuuɗi jam ɓanndu e haa yakke feere footay wonda haa kugal ngam suklugo do ɓikkon maɓɓe je ɗon saare ngam jaangirdeji ɗon maɓɓi.

en: This means that many medical professionals are not at the facilities where they are most needed during a health crisis.
ff: Ndu yiɗi wi'ugo yo'o huwooɓe ngam jam ɓanndu wonday haa wakkereji kugal je ɓe ɓuri marugo haaje maɓɓe haa ton.

en: Lack of access to technology or fast, reliable internet access can prevent students in rural areas and from disadvantaged families.
ff: Dabare je wala ngam keɓɓugo nastirde haa teknik malla haa internati je ɗon yaawa foti haɗɗa jaangoɓe haa kawyeji e je calaaje maɓɓe ɗon laffi.

en: Lack of access to technology or good internet connectivity is an obstacle to continued learning, especially for students from disadvantaged families.
ff: Dabare je wala ngam keɓɓugo nastirde haa teknik malla internati je boɗɗe laati haɗɗol nder ekkitol, ɓurna bo'o haa jaangoɓe je ummi calaaje je ɗon laffi masitin.

en: In response to school closures caused by COVID-19, UNESCO recommends the use of distance learning programmes and open educational applications and platforms that schools and teachers can use to reach learners remotely and limit the disruption of education.To aid in slowing the transmission of COVID-19, hundreds of libraries have temporarily closed.
